name: Billionaires
bio: Does the Comcast bid for Disney signal Gates&#39 entry in big media? That&#39s what some are speculating, given Microsoft&#39s 7% stake in the cable giant. Any new media deal by Comcast would likely involve Microsoft, if only to draw on the software maker&#39s $50 billion in capital. Lately, Microsoft acting more mature, paying out dividends and nixing stock options, but no less formidable: “We’re just at the beginning of what we can do with software,” proclaimed Gates at company meeting last July. Microsoft’s chief software architect pushing to move company beyond PCs into TVs, cell phones, cars, even wristwatches. Flagship Windows operating system runs 94% of the world’s desktop computers, but company facing heated pressure from Linux, whose open-source system for servers is growing more quickly than Microsoft’s. Expectations high for Windows successor, dubbed Longhorn, which might surface in 2005. Outside the office, world’s biggest philanthropist devoting billions to eradicating infectious diseases (polio, AIDS) and developing vaccines through $24 billion Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation. Methodically diversifying: sells 20 million shares a quarter, reinvests via Cascade Investments with stakes in Cox Communications, Canadian National Railway, Republic Services.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oracle of Omaha assumed Delphic role as Arnold’s economic adviser in California governorship race. Maybe because he was so dismayed with governance in the corporate sphere: “Accountability and stewardship withered in the last decade.” Takes some of the blame personally. “Too often I was silent when management made proposals that I judged to be counter to the interests of shareholders.” Otherwise an impeccable track record. Studied under investment guru Benjamin Graham at Columbia. Applied value investing principles to build Berkshire Hathaway into $116 billion (market cap) holding company: insurance (General Re, Geico), substantial stakes in American Express, Coca-Cola, Gillette, Wells Fargo. Also wide assortment of operating companies that tickle Warren’s fancy: Fruit of the Loom, Pampered Chef, NetJet. Believes Berkshire should be a “fortress of financial strength.” Has been just that: stock up nearly 50% in the past year.

name: Billionaires
bio: The undisputed supermarket king, along with younger brother, Theo. His 6,500-store Aldi chain began as a single grocery in the Ruhr Valley run until the end of WWII by their mother. The formula: Customers would rather scuttle fancy decor and services in exchange for lower prices. Despite a flagging retail sector, Aldi’s total sales in 2002 reached $49 billion—still just a fifth the size of Wal-Mart’s sales. The arrangement had Karl manage the southern, more profitable half of Germany, while younger Theo minded the north. Karl has since retired, leaving the company in the hands of nonfamily members. (His two children do not work at Aldi.) Both brothers fiercely guard their privacy, though now and again information emerges. Word is Karl raises orchids and enjoys a round of golf on his own 27-hole course.

name: Billionaires
bio: The jet-setting prince is transforming himself into a businessman-cum-political-activist. Sure, he’s still got his $10 billion stake in Citigroup. But in Saudi Arabia this nephew of the king has called for a range of reforms: elections, women’s rights and job creation. And he’s publicly criticized the state-owned oil company, Saudi Aramco.  Plus, he’s a vocal supporter of the U.S.—and has set up centers at universities in Cairo and Beirut to teach the American political system. On his latest spin through the U.S., in January, he met with former U.S. Presidents Carter, Clinton and Bush to talk about what he calls “narrowing the gap between the U.S. and Saudi Arabia.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Microsoft cofounder’s “wired world” vision not looking visionary just yet. At Vulcan Ventures, his private investment vehicle, recently replaced longtime head William Savoy with younger sister Jody Patton. Also unloaded big stake in RCN at a big loss. Still has plenty of room for risk thanks to $5 billion Microsoft stake. Increased stake in cable company Charter Communications despite indictment of four former senior execs for inflating results; dumped big investment in drug company Vaxgen, maker of failed AIDS vaccine. Dozens of other technology projects not quite ready for prime time. Perhaps better luck in bricks and mortar. Plans to develop 50-acre “bioscience hub” in Seattle with commercial, residential space; Merck already signed on as tenant. Other projects: science fiction museum alongside his Experience Music Project in Seattle. Among the collection: the original captain’s chair from Star Trek television show. Collector of vintage military airplanes, including WWII-era Spitfire, Zero. Joined Bill Gates in 1975 to start Microsoft, left in 1983 to fight Hodgkin’s disease. Slow but steady seller of big Microsoft stake ever since.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Sam Walton (d. 1992), who opened his first general store in Rogers, Ark. in 1962. Wal-Mart now world’s largest retailer: 4,000-plus stores around the globe. Family controls 38% of Wal-Mart, but prefers a passive role; Alice raises horses on Texas ranch. Family last year donated $750 million-plus, much to education, including $300 million to U. of Arkansas. But family largesse not enough to quell accusations that Wal-Mart wields too much clout. If Sam were alive today, he would be worth twice as much as Bill Gates.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest son of Sam Walton (d. 1992), who opened his first general store in Rogers, Ark. in 1962. Wal-Mart now world’s largest retailer: 4,000-plus stores around the globe. Family controls 38% of Wal-Mart, but prefers a passive role. Jim: president of Arvest, state’s biggest bank. Family last year donated $750 million-plus, much to education, including $300 million to U. of Arkansas. But family largesse not enough to quell accusations that Wal-Mart wields too much clout. If Sam were alive today, he would be worth twice as much as Bill Gates.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eldest son of Sam Walton (d. 1992), who opened his first general store in Rogers, Ark. in 1962. Wal-Mart now world’s largest retailer: 4,000-plus stores around the globe. Family controls 38% of Wal-Mart; Robson serves as chairman. Family last year donated $750 million-plus, much to education, including $300 million to U. of Arkansas. But family largesse not enough to quell accusations that Wal-Mart wields too much clout. If Sam were alive today, he would be worth twice as much as Bill Gates.

name: Billionaires
bio: France’s richest resident is some $4 billion richer this year, thanks mostly to the rising euro and the continued strength of her holdings in L&#39Oréal and Nestlé. Inherited a controlling stake in L’Oréal in 1957 from her father, the company’s founder. As discreet as she is rich, Bettencourt shuns the press. Part of the reason may be an impressive number of skeletons in the family closet, most relating to the family’s intimate association with extreme-right political groups in Vichy France. Only daughter and heir apparent Françoise Bettencourt Meyers sits on L’Oréal’s board of directors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oracle CEO upping ante in prolonged bid to buy business-software rival PeopleSoft, headed by former Oracle executive Craig Conway. Chicago native took Oracle public 1986, one day before Microsoft. Still feuding with Gates: formed alliance with Sun Microsystems to run Oracle software on Sun's Linux machines. Ellison's fortune peaked at $58 billion in 2000; he finds no irony prophesying massive consolidation for computer industry.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded $14.3 billion (sales) furniture chain Ikea in 1943; the Swede still runs the show from tax-haven Switzerland. Despite 186 stores in 31 countries—11 new ones in the last year including five in North America—Ikea achieved a modest 3% increase in sales in Fiscal Year 2003. His three sons work at Ikea and one will eventually be named successor. He flies economy, avoids wearing suits and drives a ten-year old Volvo. Said to shake the hands of all 1,000 employees who attend company’s annual meeting. Kamprad derives his wealth not only from the stores but also from ownership of most of the land Ikea stores sit on.

name: Billionaires
bio: Latin America’s richest man is $5.5 billion richer this year, thanks to windfall profits and stock surges from his flagship Téléfonos de México and América Móvil telcos. The former, a virtual landline monopoly, is notorious for undercutting the competition. On the political front, Slim, as he’s known, has become a vocal opponent of free trade and free markets prescriptions for developing Latin economies. His argument: After 20 years of clinging to that advice, the Mexicans have nothing to show for it.

name: Billionaires
bio: Soft-spoken Texan continues to dominate brutal market for personal computers by clawing his way into servers, storage and services: “I think of us as the hunter, not the hunted.” Latest task: challenging HP and Apple in printers and gadgets. Started selling computers from dorm room in 1984. Dropped out to start Dell Computer; took public in 1988. Recently selling shares; diversifies portfolio via MSD Capital.

name: Billionaires
bio: Microsoft chief executive, software industry’s fiercest cheerleader, says recent talk that tech doesn’t matter anymore is “hogwash.” Company is spending hundreds of millions in a push to beat Sony’s PlayStation in videogames and AOL in online service. Insists there’s plenty of untapped potential, albeit saw fit to ax company’s fabled employee stock option plan. Upside for shareholders: Doled out first-ever dividend this year. Native of Detroit quit Stanford M.B.A. program to join Harvard classmate (and dropout) Bill Gates in 1980. At the helm of Microsoft since 1998.

name: Billionaires
bio: Asia’s richest and most influential businessman. Centered on the conglomerates Hutchinson Whampoa and Cheung Kong, Li’s empire spans 40 countries and accounts for 11.5% of Hong Kong’s stock market value. Leading real estate developer, cell phone provider and retailer, and the only supplier of electricity in Hong Kong. Also the world’s largest operator of container terminals and one of the first outfits to offer high-speed multimedia services via cell phones in Europe and Asia. Has 1,900 retail stores in Europe. Eldest son, Victor Li, who is a Canadian citizen, recently offered $488 million for a 28% stake in bankrupted Air Canada. A dedicated philanthropist, Li has donated more than $450 million to educational causes and medical care such as nursing homes and day-care centers for the elderly.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chief of sprawling LVMH empire, peddler of must-have accoutrements for the rich and powerful. Among his brands: Dom Perignon, Fendi, Louis Vuitton, and TAG Heuer. Virtually all of Arnault’s fortune is tied up in his near-40% stake in LVMH. Thanks to a surging euro and rebound of the luxury goods sector, that stake appreciated by $4 billion last year alone. Another Arnault to watch: eldest child Delphine, 27, who last year joined the LVMH board of directors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers inherited Hong Kong&#39s giant real estate developer Sun Hung Kai Properties in 1990 following father’s death. Under their leadership, company branched out into cellular phone service under SmarTone name. Also control KMB, a large bus operator in Hong Kong. SARS slowed property sales and bus usage in the first half of 2003, but brothers are betting Hong Kong’s economy will continue to recover.

name: Billionaires
bio: With sister Barbara Cox Anthony (see), two daughters of James M. Cox (d. 1957), newspaper reporter who bought the Dayton Evening News for $26,000 in 1898. Served three terms as Ohio governor; bought more newspapers. Today sisters control 98% of Cox Enterprises: 17 daily newspapers (including flagship Atlanta Journal-Constitution), 15 TV stations, 78 radio stations, cable systems (6.5 million users). Barbara: keeps low profile in Hawaii. Anne: former ambassador to Belgium under Carter.

name: Billionaires
bio: Abramovich lost his parents as a child, dropped out of college and then made a fortune in a series of controversial oil export deals in the early 1990s. His fortunes took off in 1995, when he teamed up with Russia’s most powerful crony capitalist, Boris Berezovsky, to take over oil giant Sibneft at a fraction of its market value. When Berezovsky fled Russia in 2000 to escape fraud charges, he sold out to Abramovich. Now besides Sibneft, Abramovich has interests in aluminum, TV and automobiles—all held by British-registered Millhouse Capital. Recently blocked merger of Sibneft with rival Yukos (controlled by imprisoned oligarch Mikhail Khodorkovsky); sold part of his auto and aluminum business to partner Oleg Deripaska. These days spending his fortune conspicuously—including paying $400 million for London’s Chelsea football club and some of the world’s best players.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of Frank and Ethel Mars, candymakers who struck profitable sweet spot with Milky Way bar in 1923. Mars Inc. now one of nation’s largest confectioners: M&Ms, Snickers, 3 Musketeers, Twix, Skittles. Also pet food (Whiskas, Sheba, Pedigree), Uncle Ben’s rice, electronic components for vending machines. Siblings (see John, Jacqueline) preside over $17 billion (estimated sales) food empire, but day-to-day business handled by co-presidents Benno Hoogendoorn and Peter Cheney.

name: Billionaires
bio: Italy’s wealthiest man has been its prime minister since 2001. Recent reports say his corruption trial will resume mid-April, after Italy’s highest court overturned a controversial law that gave Berlusconi immunity from prosecution while in office. His investment holding company, Fininvest, owns almost half of Mediaset, one of Italy’s largest television networks. Also has banking, insurance and publishing interests. Still has time for leisure pursuits: recently released a CD of love songs for which he wrote many of the lyrics. Also reportedly enjoys gardening. His AC Milan soccer team won the European Cup last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Abigail, with father Edward, runs Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest mutual fund company. Riding recent stock market rally: assets under management grew 28% to $988 billion in 2003. Latest growth engine: Employer Services, provider of human resources and retirement services.

name: Billionaires
bio: With her three children, inherited packaging giant Tetra Laval in January 2000 after her husband Gad’s death. Lives in tax-haven Switzerland. Son Finn lives in Sweden, while other son, Jörn, and daughter, Kirsten, prefer England. Tetra Laval, which recently completed acquisition of French company Sidel SA, has sales of $11 billion and an 80% share of the packaging industry

name: Billionaires
bio: Spain’s richest man and one of the richest self-made entrepreneurs in Europe. Press-shy and supercasual (won’t wear a tie). With the help of ex-wife and fellow billionaire Rosalia Mera founded Spanish textile company Inditex, in 1985. Best known for its Zara retail stores. Despite the global recession, the company opened over 360 new stores in 2003. Has made personal investments in a variety of sectors, including biomedical research, electric and gas, banking and tourism. Reportedly loves horses and owns an impressive collection of modern art.

name: Billionaires
bio: No love lost for regulators. First, feds canned EchoStar’s $25 billion bid for DirecTV only to accept rival $6.6 billion bid by Rupert Murdoch for controlling stake. Silver lining: outpacing larger DirecTV in new customers, 1.4 million vs. 1.1 million, in 2002. Former Frito-Lay financial analyst started EchoStar in 1980 to beam pictures to rural customers; today it has 9 million subscribers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Irrepressible media magnate turned out to be a wishy-washy bidder for Vivendi Universal,perhaps because he harbors bigger fancy for Disney. Son of drive-in-theater owner, took over Dad’s business in 1954, built National Amusements into 1,400-screen chain. Reaped big gains in 1980s flipping stock in takeover targets Twentieth Century Fox (bought by News Corp.) and Columbia Pictures (bought by Sony). Big growth ever since: Viacom now owns CBS, Infinity Broadcasting, Paramount, Nickelodeon, MTV, Blockbuster. Maintaining delicate symbiosis with second-in-command Mel Karmazin. Daughter, Shari, who is on the board but not active in the company, waits in the wings.

name: Billionaires
bio: The sixth Duke of Westminister, still the richest man in the U.K., is a megalandlord in London’s tony Mayfair and Belgravia, with an additional 150,000 acres in the English countryside. Though high-end property prices in London softened after years of heady growth, Grosvenor was cushioned by the sheer vastness of his real estate empire, which stretches from Hong Kong to the suburbs of Washington, D.C.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Hennes & Mauritz, the Swedish clothing chain established by father, Erling, in 1947. The $7.7 billion (sales) chain has 801 stores in 14 countries. Will be opening its first 5 stores in Canada this year. Sits on boards with several other billionaires: Fredrik Lungberg at Stockholm School of Economics; Ingvar Kamprad at Ikea’s holding company Ingka Holding ; and Dietrich Mateschitz at the Mentor charitable foundation. Enjoys downhill skiing, tennis and golf

name: Billionaires
bio: Pursuing promise to donate all but 1% of his wealth to philanthropy, though Ebay’s surging stock price makes finding enough deserving recipients difficult. Last July gave $280 million in Ebay stock to unidentified charity. French émigré launched online auctioneer in 1995. Settled on name at trademark office after discovering first choice, EchoBay, already taken. IPO in 1998. Ebay now generates over $2 billion in sales by connecting buyers and sellers for everything from farm equipment to Elvis memorabilia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns M.A. Kharafi & Sons, a $3.3 billion (revenues) conglomerate based in Kuwait. Nasser runs the business while older brother Jassim plays the politician. (Sister Faiza is president of Kuwait University.) Also getting pieces of Iraqi action: National Bank of Kuwait, in which family owns an estimated 16%, is part of consortium of banks that is rebuilding the banking market in Iraq. Also working with Halliburton unit in Iraq on a U.S. Army-awarded contract. Other contracts include $110 million Beirut hotel, $200 million golf and residential development in South Africa and $400 million sewage plant in Kuwait. The family-owned, Disneyesque Port Galib on Egypt’s Red Sea coast attracted 25 flights a week from Europe and 800 visiting yachts last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to her father’s 50.1% stake in pharmaceutical manufacturer Altana. (Her father, Herbert Quandt, was himself famous for rescuing BMW from bankruptcy.) A trained economist—she boasts an M.B.A. from the IMD business school in Lausanne—she has helped launch Altana, with $3.3 billion in sales last year, on Germany’s DAX index of the top 30 companies by trade volume and market cap. She herself claims a 12.5% share of BMW, which (along with Porsche) is one of the last independent luxury car makers. The press-shy heiress is seldom in the public eye.

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of Otto GmbH, the world’s largest mail-order company, with $24 billion in sales last year. Thanks to a 30% rise in Internet sales last year, Otto also maintains its position as the Web’s second-biggest retailer, behind Amazon.com. Business hasn’t fared as well at their venerable Spiegel Co., which filed for bankruptcy last March. Otto and his family own extensive real estate in Canada and the U.S., shopping centers in Germany and part of home-furnishings chain Crate & Barrel. Known as a committed environmentalist, his company has long touted environmentally safe products.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Ruben Rausing, founded packaging company Tetra Laval in 1944. Moved to England in the early 1980 to avoid Sweden’s punitive taxes. In 1995 sold his share in Tetra Laval to brother Gad for a reported $7 billion. Lives on a 900-acre East Sussex estate, where he raises deer and collects vintage cars. Reportedly has bought land in New Zealand and owns stakes in Swedish crystal company Orrefors Kosta Boda and a Ukrainian ketchup maker. Also invested in Ecolean, which he helped found to make biodegradable packaging; has yet to turn a profit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started with one newspaper in Adelaide, Australia. Now a titan in television (35 stations, Fox Network), movies (Twentieth Century Fox), newspapers (New York Post, U.K.’s Sun). Operating income up 25% last year, led by strong showing in television (Joe Millionaire, American Idol) and DVD sales. “Fair and balanced” Fox News Channel (host to Forbes on Fox) defied critics with solid lead over rival CNN. Expanded already vast empire with $6.6 billion purchase of controlling stake in satellite service DirecTV from General Motors. Sprightly septuagenarian shows no signs of retiring; last year fathered sixth child with wife, Wendi.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Samuel Irving Jr. (see), son of Sam Newhouse, who took over failing Staten Island Advance 1922 and built what was once the nation’s largest newspaper chain. Sons inherited Advance Publications after father’s death in 1979. Donald runs newspapers (Cleveland Plain Dealer, Newark’s Star-Ledger), Si oversees glamorous Condé Nast magazine division (Vogue, Vanity Fair, the New Yorker). Also owns Sunday newspaper insert Parade, Fairchild Publications (Women’s Wear Daily).

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Donald, son of Sam Newhouse, who took over failing Staten Island Advance 1922 and built what was once the nation’s largest newspaper chain. Sons inherited Advance Publications after father’s death in 1979. Donald runs newspapers (Cleveland Plain Dealer, Newark’s Star-Ledger), Si oversees glamorous Condé Nast magazine division (Vogue, Vanity Fair, the New Yorker). Also owns Sunday newspaper insert Parade, Fairchild Publications (Women’s Wear Daily).

name: Billionaires
bio: Another busy year for the chairman and president of George Weston Ltd., one of North America&#39s largest bakers. Aside from tending to his controlling stake in Loblaw&#39s, Canada’s largest supermarket chain, Weston also minds upscale retailers Holt Renfrew and Brown Thomas. Last year acquired London-based department store Selfridges for $958 million through his Whittington Investments. Strong outlook for 2004: as a manufacturer of Atkins products in North America, Weston looks to cash in on low-carb craze but Interbake Foods&#39 division manufactures calories old-fashioned way for Girl Scout cookies. An avid collector of avant-garde artist Christo, Weston regularly host exhibitions showcasing the work of influential artists at a gallery founded by his daughter, Alannah, at Windsor, his private community in Vero Beach, Fla.

name: Billionaires
bio: Corporate-takeover titan not slowing down yet. Still using old tactics: in 2002 wrested ailing XO Communications from Ted Forstmann (see) through big bond buy; stake now worth $710 million. Scored big in 1980s with takeovers of Texaco, USX and TWA. Now solidifying Las Vegas stakes: owns three hotel casinos, including the 1,150-foot Stratosphere. Also owns the Sands in Atlantic City. In January donated $10 million to New York City Parks department to help build a $40 million track-and-field stadium on Randall's Island.

name: Billionaires
bio: Messy carve-up underway for Chicago's Pritzker family. Reins were passing from Robert and brother, Jay (d. 1999), to Jay's son Thomas, who, with cousins Nicholas and Penny, runs Pritzker Organization's far-flung assets: Hyatt hotels, Marmon manufacturing conglomerate, Royal Caribbean Cruises, Conwood tobacco. Instead, family fortune to be split among a dozen or so cousins.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bertarelli has the wind in his sails. After leading landlocked Switzerland to an America’s Cup win in April 2003 with his Team Alinghi, he returned full speed to the helm of Serono, the Swiss biotech concern he inherited from his father in 1996. Credited with transforming Serono from drug firm to world biotech leader. He’s looking to make Serono a household name with breakthroughs in infertility and muscular dystrophy meds. At one time one of the world’s most eligible bachelors, settled down to marry a former British beauty queen and has two children.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sultan of Swoosh's net worth is on the rise, thanks to improving market at home and pricey endorsements from NBA superstars like Carmelo Anthony. Former U. of Oregon runner got his start in 1964 selling shoes out of his car at track meets. Owns computer animation shop Vinton Studios, creator of television ads (California Raisins, M&Ms) and animated shorts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Famed financier turned political advocate now obsessed with ousting President Bush from office. Published new book "The Bubble of American Supremacy" in December. Still playing the markets: Flagship Quantum Endowment hedge fund has $7.4 billion under management. Renowned for making big bets: reaped $1 billion in 1992 speculation on the British pound; lost $2 billion during Russian crisis 1998. Known for philanthropy and humanitarian work: Network of foundations donates more than $450 million a year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Workaholic founder and chairman of Luxottica, a $3 billion (sales) designer and manufacturer of high-quality eyeglass frames. The company owns the Ray-Ban brand and U.S. retailers LensCrafters and Sunglass Hut. Recently announced plans to buy Cole National, owner of optical chain Pearle Vision. Sells sunglasses under designer names such as Prada and Versace. Del Vecchio recently joined Versace’s board. Sent to an orphanage at age 7 because his mother could not afford to support her five children. Apprentice at a factory that made molds for auto parts, eyeglass frames; opened his own molding shop in 1958 at the age of 23. Apparently flies helicopter to work. Son Claudio owns men’s retailer Brooks Brothers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Descendant of banker Wilhelm von Finck, founder of insurance giant Allianz and private bank Merck, Finck & Co., which he sold to Barclays in 1990. From his tax hideaway in Switzerland, overseas a diversified portfolio with investments in mining, chemicals, insurance, property rental and leasing, retailers, hotels, restaurants, even a champagne producer. Older brother Wilhelm died at the age of 76 last October

name: Billionaires
bio: Indian software supremo Azim Premji’s Wipro, of which he owns 84%, successfully weathered a challenging year of pricing pressures, rising costs and antioutsourcing sentiments. Although software services revenues touched $1 billion and margins improved in the year’s second half, Wipro’s stock rose only 12%. Continuing his acquisitive streak, Premji paid $19 million for U.S.-based NerveWire, an IT consulting firm specializing in financial services. He’s moved into a new house, right next to Wipro’s offices, and walks to work every morning. Younger son Tariq works for nonprofit Azim Premji Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns and operates Delton, a $1.3 billion (sales) holding company whose subsidiaries include a homeopathic drugmaker, logistics company and electric utility outfit. Also owns 77% of CEAG, a publicly traded power supply equipment maker, as well as smart-card maker Data Card Corp. The great bulk of his wealth, however, comes from his 17.4% stake in luxury auto maker BMW. Rumor has it he may eventually head BMW’s supervisory board. Studied engineering and economics at Karlsruhe Technical University before stints at Boston Consulting and Datacard Asia Pacific. Young, good looking and with so many billions, he remains a much sought-after bachelor.

name: Billionaires
bio: The outspoken heir to Dassault computer and aviation businesses is $3.2 billion richer this year. Thank the French government, which awarded Dassault Aviation the sole contract to develop a military fighter drone, guaranteeing state largesse to the firm for years to come. Dassault the man also made headlines with plans to develop modular housing for French towns and to mass-market electric cars with partner Hydro-Québec. Also threatened to move civilian airplane production out of France if the euro stays strong, naming the U.S. a possible alternative.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fortunes of this real estate baron are turning around. His flagship Henderson Land posted a 4% increase in net profits and 23% jump in sales last year. Looking ahead to the 2008 Olympics in Beijing, Lee recently completed a $385 million stock placement to invest in four new hotels in Beijing and Hong Kong.

name: Billionaires
bio: This steel titan oversees LNM Group, the world’s second-largest steelmaker, behind Luxembourg-based Arcelor. Among LNM’s holdings is Ispat International, which posted $4.8 billion in sales in 2002. Mittal keeps acquiring steel mills in emerging markets: Nova Hut in the Czech Republic, Polski Huty Stali in Poland, Petrotub in Romania. Upped his stake in Africa’s largest steel producer to 49.9%. Now has mills in 13 countries, including the U.S. Son, Aditya, is LNM Holdings’ vice chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mother and son jointly own INA Waelzlager Schaeffler KG, one of the world’s largest producers of roller bearings.That top spot came after a suprise acquisition in 2001  of publicly listed FAG Kugelfisher Georg Schäfer. Since her husband’s death in 1996 Maria Elizabeth has been running the $86 billion private company, leaving Georg free to practice international law in Dallas at Haynes and Boone. Mother and son guard their privacy. Still, she’s a well-known figure in Bavaria, holding a post in the Nuremberg Chamber of Commerce and Industry. She was awarded the Bavarian Order of Merit last July for her services to the region and its citizens.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ambani brothers Mukesh, 46, and Anil, 44, are on a roll; stock price of flagship Reliance Industries, in which they hold a 34% stake, doubled last year. Reliance is now India’s second most valuable company after state-owned oil giant ONGC.  The $18.1 billion (assets) group consolidated its hold in petrochemicals with a domestic acquisition and an R&D alliance with Dupont. Telecom company Reliance Infocomm picked up more than 6 million customers in its first year, competing successfully against fellow billionaire Sunil Mittal in India’s fast-growing wireless industry. With an eye on global markets, the brothers paid $211 million for London-based Flag Telecom, an optical fiber network provider. Fitness fanatic Anil took part in Bombay’s first-ever marathon recently.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third fling with MGM a little rocky: Earnings still scarce despite successful James Bond flick Die Another Day and comedy Legally Blonde II. Company announced $170 million buyback of 10 million shares in January. Gaming company MGM-Mirage faring much better: stock up 60% since February 2003. Incredibly, still pursing $1 billion lawsuit against DaimlerChrysler over 1998 merger. He testified in early December.

name: Billionaires
bio: Budding real estate fortune built on the back of Beanie Babies. Plush-toy maker owns two Four Seasons hotels; last year added Chicago office complex, Sandpiper golf course near Santa Barbara, Calif. Dedicated proceeds from “Ronnie” bear go to upgrade living quarters of crew members serving aboard Navy’s newest aircraft carrier, the U.S.S. Ronald Reagan.

name: Billionaires
bio: American on his mother’s side, Engelhorn retired to Switzerland with fourth wife, Heidemarie, cushioned by the $4.4 billion proceeds he pocketed from the sale of pharmaceutical firms Boehringer Mannheim and DePuy Inc. (in which together he had a 40% stake)to Roche in 1997. His Engelhorn Foundation for Rare Diseases hasn’t been as successful. The fund was liquidated last year, apparently on the heels of losses incurred due to embezzlement of funds by the foundation manager.

name: Billionaires
bio: Focused on charity ever since resigning as chief of financial giant SunAmerica in 2000. Latest pledge: $100 million to create new medical institute dedicated to human genome research, to be run by Harvard and MIT. Contemporary-art fiend promised $60 million to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

name: Billionaires
bio: After growing up in the Ukrainian city of Lvov, Fridman came to Moscow to study at the Institute of Steel & Alloys in the 1980s. Founded Alfa Group in 1988 with college friends; now diverse conglomerate with oil, retail, telecom, Russia’s largest private bank. Strong Kremlin connections, including a former subordinate who serves as Putin’s chief political adviser. Last year merged his oil company, TNK, with the Russian oil interests of BP—quite an achievement, considering that five years ago BP was in a bitter fight against what it claimed were Fridman’s unorthodox methods in taking over a partly BP-owned oilfield. But that’s Fridman’s style: aggressive, highly leveraged takeovers, followed by reorganization and then a sale to a strategic investor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Own and tightly control Chanel, founded by grandfather Pierre Wertheimer. The ultrasecretive brothers are big-time equestrians. Their filly Halfbridled won a Breeders’ Cup race in California last year. And Alain reportedly unloaded his $3 million Litchfield County, Conn. country home last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Intel in 1968 with Robert Noyce and $2.5 million investment arranged by venture capitalist Arthur Rock. Lent name to theory on the exponential growing power of computer chips (Moore’s Law). Company became world’s largest chipmaker, now thriving in server and wireless equipment markets. Donated half his holdings to charitable foundation for education-based philanthropy, environmental conservation. Recent donations include $300 million to alma mater, Caltech.

name: Billionaires
bio: The charismatic cofounder of software giant SAP stepped down from daily management last May. That leaves him plenty of time to pursue his various hobbies. A sports enthusiast, Plattner skis, snowboards and plays tennis, but is best known as an internationally competitive sailor—he sailed against Larry Ellison of Oracle in the Kenwood Cup. An avid golfer, he and his wife Sabine own Fancourt Estate, a luxury hotel and golf course in South Africa, which hosted the Presidents Cup last November. .

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of industrialist Herbert Quandt, who resurrected BMW from bankruptcy. First his secretary before becoming his third wife, she enjoys a 16.7% stake in BMW. Along with children Susanne and Stephan, controls one of the most powerful family fortunes in Germany. Retired from the supervisory board of BMW in 1997 and now lives unobtrusively in the spa town of Bad Homburg near Frankfurt.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former oilman parlayed railroad land into Qwest Communications; telecom highflier until sunk by fiber optics meltdown, accounting scandal, shareholder lawsuits. Has holdings in movie theaters (Regal Entertainment), oil (Pacific Energy Partners), railroads (Union Pacific). Stakes in pro basketball’s Lakers, hockey’s Kings. Last year agreed to make $4.4 million in charitable donations to settle charges of receiving IPO stock in exchange for business.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1982 succeeded her father as chair of A. Johnson & Co., a diversified trading company founded by her great-grandfather in 1873. The privately held $9 billion company (sales) spans industry, energy, real estate, telecom and food retailing (Axfood AB is one of the largest food operations in Scandinavia). Received an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree from Middlebury College in Vermont

name: Billionaires
bio: Thriving Internet bookseller and "new economy" survivor pushing clothes, garden tools, cookware, music. Stock—and net worth—soared 200% from a low in summer 2002, though the gregarious founder insists: “I don’t keep track of daily stock swings.” Now turning his attention from cyberspace to outer space: founded Blue Origin to develop a reusable spaceship for extraterrestrial tourism.

name: Billionaires
bio: Came almost out of nowhere to buy British Home Stores (now BHS), the U.K.’s fifth-largest retail chain, in May 2000. Two years later bought the country’s second-largest clothing retailer, Arcadia Group Ltd. Together, the companies boast 40,000 employees, 2,500 outlets and $5.1 billion in sales. Lives part-time in a hotel in London while his wife, Tina, and two children reside in a Monte Carlo penthouse.

name: Billionaires
bio: New York City mayor tries to manage the Big Apple like his company, but voters—and angry smokers—are much harder to appease than employees. Budget cuts have angered unions, driving down approval ratings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Controversial shareholder in Japan Airlines (JAL). This former politician, who admits to having friends who are gangsters, is now a major adviser to JAL. On his own Web site he discusses his desire to change JAL’s management. Since 1969 has run a golf/resort company; son and wife both sit on board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Edward, along with daughter Abigail, runs Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest mutual fund company. Riding recent stock market rally: Assets under management grew 28% to $988 billion in 2003. Latest growth engine: Employer Services, provider of human resources and retirement services.

name: Billionaires
bio: A former Soviet foreign trade official, Potanin teamed up with banker Mikhail Prokhorov in 1992 to take over assets of two Soviet-era foreign trade banks. Later won control of metals giant Norilsk Nickel and oil company Sidanco in controversial “loans-for-shares” auctions. Served as deputy prime minister in charge of the economy in 1996-97; then partnered with George Soros to invest in telecom monopoly Svyazinvest but sold out to his U.S. partner after a falling-out. The devaluation of the ruble in 1998 forced the liquidation of his Uneximbank; sold his oil interests to Mikhail Fridman’s Alfa Group. His Interros holding company remains broadly diversified, with interests in metals, insurance, media, agriculture and engineering. Last year bought the last remaining U.S. platinum and palladium producer, Stillwater Mining, for $255 million. Now paying attention to his social standing, joining board of the Guggenheim Museum in 2002.

name: Billionaires
bio: Moscow State Financial Institute graduate worked in one of the big Soviet foreign trade banks; teamed up with Vladimir Potanin to take over the assets of two banks being liquidated. Now their venture Interros includes metals, engineering, agriculture and media; since 2001 Prokhorov has been chairman of its most valuable holding, metals conglomerate Norilsk Nickel; has a slightly larger stake than his longtime partner. A bachelor, Prokhorov is often featured in gossip columns about blowout parties on the French Riviera. But then it’s back to work at his metals plant in the Arctic Circle.

name: Billionaires
bio: An annus horribilus, begun when his Pinault-Printemps-Redoute paid California $185 million to resolve federal criminal charges relating to the Executive Life Insurance scandal. Even so, the state’s attorney general and Department of Insurance are waging civil suits against Pinault. Meanwhile, PPR struggles to find suitable replacements for Gucci’s departing dream team, designer Tom Ford and chief executive Domenico De Sole. Son François-Henri took the helm of the retail empire last year, a signal that Pinault, the self-made son of a timber trader, is nearing retirement?

name: Billionaires
bio: A tumultuous year for Israel’s richest citizen. Israeli media castigated her for her recent third marriage to businessman Ofer Glazer, the subject of sexual harassment allegations. Her Bank Hapoalim had historic layoffs last year, which also won her no favorability points with the press. Had enough, Arison decamped from Israel to make a new home in Miami. Now an ex (second marriage) is suing her for custody of their son. Silver lining: Shari added nearly $2 billion to her coffers, thanks to a doubling in value of her Carnival Corp. shares. The cruise line, managed by brother Micky Arison, fared well last year thanks to a successful megamerger with P&O Princess.

name: Billionaires
bio: Latin television baron derives much of his wealth from a big stake in Univision, the U.S. Spanish-language network. Back home in Caracas, his television stations bitterly denounce leftist dictator Hugo Chavez, who in turn derides Cisneros and fellow media magnates as the "Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse." Chavez's increasing alignment with Castro doesn't bode well for Cisneros's homegrown media companies, a tempting target for nationalization. No fool, Cisneros has already moved many of his operations to the United States.

name: Billionaires
bio: The beer maiden inherited a 25% controlling stake in the world&#39s third-largest brewer from father, Alfred, upon his death two years ago. De Carvalho-Heineken, however, has no plans to take on a management role. Maybe she should reconsider. Even power-brand Heineken wasn’t resistant to global issues like a weak economy, war in Iraq and SARS—earnings are flat, sales for the first half of 2003 up just 1%. Lives in London with investment banker husband, Michel de Carvalho, a former child actor who appeared in the 1962 epic Lawrence of Arabia. The mother of five children enjoys photography, music and architecture. Also a member of St. Moritz’s exclusive Corviglia Ski Club.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded the Massa chain of German department stores in 1948. Sold the chain in 1985, but retained the underlying real estate, which he now rents to giant retailer Metro. Also owns extensive real estate holdings in New York City and four luxe hotels in Switzerland. His only son, Florida resident Ernst-Ludwig, died last September at the age of 53

name: Billionaires
bio: His Jim Pattison Holdings is Canada’s third-largest private company. Begun with a single Buick dealership in 1961, Pattison’s annual sales of $4.2 billion now come from such diverse holdings as Ripley’s Believe It Or Not! shows and tourist attractions, car dealerships, billboards, radio stations, packaging and food stores. Last year he even snapped up $40 million worth of shares in drugmaker Biovail from fellow Canuck mogul Eugene Melnyk; already sitting on 40% gain. When it rains in Vancouver, Pattison escapes to the Palm Springs home he bought from Frank Sinatra.

name: Billionaires
bio: After 38 years at the helm of this well-known Italian fashion brand, Benetton is pulling back from the day-to-day activity. Remains chairman. Will also keep his luxurious office, decked out in 17th-century ceiling frescoes. Through a holding company, also owns 37% of Autostrade, an operator of nearly two-thirds of Italy’s motorways and 67% of Autogrill, a chain of roadside restaurants. Enjoys a reputation as one of Europe’s most famous patrons of the arts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Past problems at Computer Associates—a government investigation into accounting practices, an indicted former executive, shareholder lawsuits—sent many investors fleeing. Not Haefner, who upped his stake in the embattled company by 10.5 million shares in the fall. An even bolder move was loaning ex-CEO Charles Wang money to make a play for the New Jersey Nets. (Wang lost out to Brooklyn developer Bruce Ratner.) Haefner’s big wins usually happen at the track. He owns Ireland’s Moyglare Stud Farm and recently retired former winner Dressed To Thrill.

name: Billionaires
bio: Haub has retired from Tengelmann Group, Germany’s largest food retailer ($35.5 billion in sales in 2003), leaving sons Karl-Erivan, Georg and Christian to run the show. Karl-Erivan’s restructuring efforts, a response to Germany’s miserable retail climate, are beginning to show positive results. Meanwhile Christian Haub is trying to revive the venerable a&p chain, America’s oldest supermarket, which has suffered the one-two punch of a market slowdown and the aggressive competition of rivals. All three Haub sons were born stateside, and are therefore American citizens.

name: Billionaires
bio: Net worth doubled this year thanks to a rising share price. Founded Aiful when he was a teenager; now Japan’s fifth-largest consumer finance company. In an effort to distance company from tainted image of a loan shark, Fukuda successfully expanded into other types of loans, such as credit loans and commerce/industry loans.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father John died this April. Meanwhile the empire continues to grow under the capable hands of Spiro, who is a graduate of the London School of Economics. The family’s largest holding is its EFG Bank Group, a large banking conglomerate with private banking operations in Monaco, the United Kingdom and Switzerland. The group’s subsidiaries include the publicly traded EFG Eurobank Ergasias. Merged with the Sandoz family’s Banque Edouard Constant last year, becoming the majority shareholder. Sold its oil refining concern for a stake in Hellenic Petroleum, a large European oil refining and distribution outfit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Africa’s richest man derives most of his wealth from De Beers, the diamond giant he took private in 2001. Taking more active role in South Africa’s future: last year spearheaded economic summit attended by the likes of South Africa’s President Thabo Mbeki. That event launched the Brenthurst Initiative, designed to stimulate South African growth. Because of a long-standing U.S. antitrust case against De Beers, the Oppenheimers could be served with legal papers should they enter the United States. As a result, it’s unclear whether Nicky and family will attend the opening of the first De Beers-branded store in New York later this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Auction king. Ebay’s first president and full-time employee, Skoll is no longer involved in day-to-day but remains its second-largest shareholder. Good thing: Ebay’s shares rose more than 85% in 2003. Skoll has endowed his eponymous Skoll Foundation with at least $250 million, which last year  gave away more than $15 million in grants and loans to “social entrepreneurs” worldwide. Also an investor in Ovation Entertainment, a southern California film production outfit whose purpose is to make movies about social issues and people doing good. Pumped gas in North York, Ont. before getting an M.B.A. from Stanford in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took over his father’s tiny wholesale screw business at 19 and built it into the Adolf Würth Group, which posted record $6.7 billion in sales in 2002. The worldwide economic slump hit home, with sales in Germany down 3.1% in 2002 due to the sluggish construction industry. Würth has retired from daily affairs, but keeps a watchful eye on the business. Meantime, he maintains a sizeable collection of contemporary art which includes works by such artists as Picasso, Max Beckmann, Miro and Alfred Hrdilicka..

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chairman of Sankyo, one of the three major pachinko (slot) machine makers in Japan. Holds 20% share of the industry. Stock price is up 30% in the past year due to new models. Son Hideyuki is now the company’s chief executive. Not much is known about Busujima except that he has donated a total of $2 million to the local government and he is one of Japan’s 100 biggest tax payers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Quintessential Asian businessman whose reach extends across the region. His empire includes the Shangri-La hotel chain, the daily South China Morning Post, real estate developer Kerry Properties. Got start trading rice and then sugar in Malaysia in the 1950s and 1960s. Nowadays under pressure: His near-monopoly in sugar is being championed by a local competitor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Young patriarch of the Mendoza family. The 38-year-old oversees one of Venezuela’s largest private companies, $2.3 billion (sales) Empresas Polar. The group was founded by his grandfather as a beer company in 1941.  Now every kitchen in Venezuela is filled with their products, from wine and beer to tuna fish, flour and condiments.  Mendoza and his family shun the limelight, only occasionally appearing in society pages in connection with their charitable foundation, Fundacion Polar, one of Venezuela’s largest

name: Billionaires
bio: The man who earned billions by charming Sam Walton into expanding south of the border. His Cifra retail chain partnered with Wal-Mart in the early Nineties and was later bought out and renamed Wal-Mex. Spanish-born Arango, who briefly sat on the Wal-Mart board in the late Nineties, is no longer active in either company. Instead focuses his attention on his luxury resort in Acapulco. Arango’s wife has plans to build a museum of Mexican folklore in Mexico City.

name: Billionaires
bio: America’s richest landlord quietly bought back the remaining preferred shares of profitable Irvine Apartment Communities. But couldn’t avoid spotlight after lawsuit filed by former girlfriend seeking financial support for two illegitimate children. Big giver to educational causes, also raised funds for Arnold Schwarzenegger&#39s gubernatorial campaign.

name: Billionaires
bio: “I have no interest in making money anymore. Everything I make in the entertainment business will go to charity.” So said Hollywood’s richest man when asked what he intends to do with any money from DreamWorks SKG, founded with Jeffrey Katzenberg and Steven Spielberg (see both). Has already pledged $200 million to UCLA&#39s medical school.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Koch Industries founder Fred Koch (d. 1967). With brother David, bought out shares in business from brothers William and Fred, expanded refining and ranching businesses into chemicals, pipelines, asphalt, financing and nylon. Bought DuPont’s Textiles & Interiors business—makers of Lycra and Stainmaster—for $4.4 billion last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Koch Industries founder Fred Koch (d. 1967). With brother Charles, bought out shares in business from brothers William and Fred, expanded refining and ranching businesses into chemicals, pipelines, asphalt, financing and nylon. Bought DuPont’s Textiles & Interiors business—makers of Lycra and Stainmaster—for $4.4 billion last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owes his fortune to the family’s eponymous grocery business, but spends his days as Tony Blair’s Minister of Science. Sainsbury uses the post, which he’s held for six years, to tackle big issues like the underrepresentation of women in the field to the importance of bioscience as an economic growth driver. Was recently awarded the Andrew Carnegie Medal of Philanthropy, joining former recipients including Bill Gates, Ted Turner and George Soros. The award recognizes his long history of charity, starting at age 27 when he established the Gatsby Charitable Foundation, which awards grants in a range of fields, including mental health and African aid.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hong Kong and Shanghai Hotels were originally run by brothers Elly and Ellis Kadoorie, emigres from Baghdad, nearly 100 years ago. Michael, grandson of Elly, now oversees the family’s interests, which include power supplier CLP Holdings and hotels. Their jewel hotel, the Peninsula in Hong Kong, which had only nine guests at the peak of the SARS outbreak, celebrated its 75th anniversary last December.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded by father K.C. Irving, the Irving conglomerate operates dozens of companies that together dominate the economy of New Brunswick and Maritime Canada. The supersecretive brothers manage a labyrinthine collection of assets, including Canada’s biggest oil refinery, in St. John, 1.6 million acres of Maine timberland and 600 filing stations and truck stops. Their Kent Building Supply continues to stave off Home Depot encroachment in Atlantic Canada. Much of the family’s trust rumored to be held in tax-haven Bermuda. Last year caught up in a minor political scandal after prominent Canadian politicians were resoundingly criticized for taking free flights on Irving’s private jet and vacationing at their massive New Brunswick estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: A proletarian success story; Lisin’s career began in 1975, when he took his first job—as a mechanic in a coal mine. Then finished the Siberian Metallurgical Institute, took a job as a steelworker, rose up the ranks, got further educational degrees, eventually rising to deputy head of one of Soviet Union’s biggest steel mills. In 1991, when his boss was appointed Minister of Metallurgy, Lisin came with him to Moscow. In 1992 joined up with tough group of traders who called themselves the Trans-World Group; they came to dominate Russia’s aluminum and steel exports; Lisin managed the factories. When the partners went their separate ways in 2000, Lisin got a majority stake in Russia’s giant Novolipetsk steel mill as his share.

name: Billionaires
bio: LBO king gave up cigars and rebounded in 2002 with sale of California’s Golden State Bancorp to Citigroup; used much of the proceeds to pay off debts from dud deals like Sunbeam. Still trying to salvage 83% stake in debt-crippled Revlon. Bought majority stake in Allied Security for $300 million in February 2003. Also dropped $1 million into SIGA Technologies, biotech firm fighting sexually transmitted diseases and bioterrorism.

name: Billionaires
bio: Two-time presidential candidate sold Electronic Data Systems to General Motors in 1984 for $2.5 billion. With 8 associates formed IT consultancy Perot Systems. Business now run by son Ross Jr.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive of publicly traded Mashreqbank, U.S., family’s most valuable holding worth an estimated $2 billion to it. U.S.- educated Al Ghurair wants a broader base of regional and international investors for the bank. His Uncle Saif’s megamalls almost make him a billionaire in his own right. Brother Essa, who went to college in San Diego, operates the second-largest flour-milling company in the Mideast; counted among the ten largest global producers. Grandparents made a bundle during pearl-diving heyday; later diversified into banking, food production and real estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Location, location, location. Decaux, 66, has spent the past four decades slapping advertisements on bus-stop shelters, public toilets and billboards in bustling cities like Hong Kong, Chicago and Paris. Last year the company, JC Decaux, netted new contracts in smallish European cities like Leicester, England and Córdoba, Spain. Decaux now eyeing the big prize, New York City, set for bidding later this year. While Decaux chairs the supervisory board, sons Jean-François and Jean-Charles run the business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owner of the eponymous chocolate maker, one of Europe’s largest with estimated 2002 sales of $4 billion. Brands include Ferrero Rocher, Nutella, Tic Tac and Kinder Eggs. Recently dropped Nutella spokesman Kobe Bryant, largely due to the sexual assault charge against him. Passions: church and chocolate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Chicago financier Henry Crown (d. 1990), who created Material Service with two brothers in 1919, merged with General Dynamics 1959. Lester controls family holdings, including large stakes in Maytag, Bank One and pro basketball’s Chicago Bulls. Major benefactor of Jewish charities, universities and the Aspen Institute.

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened the stock market to the masses, first with discount brokerage, then online trading. Mending wounds after a three-year market slump, looking for upscale clients after $365 million purchase of State Street Private Asset Management. Gave up co-chief-executive spot but remains chairman, company’s public face.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth-generation gummaker with brands Doublemint, Juicy Fruit and Spearmint, looking to expand business. Created new position of chief innovation officer; introduced spicier ad campaigns for new brands like Orbit. Diversifying into breath strips, mints. Failed $12.5 billion bid to acquire Hershey Foods leaves plenty of room for other acquisitions.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns 25% of Formula One; had been sparring with rebellious car manufacturers that threatened to defect after their contracts ran out in 2007. In December finally reached an agreement giving the manufacturer’s teams a higher share of revenue and more say but keeping Ecclestone firmly at the helm. Also in December, Bernie was given a medal by the Kingdom of Bahrain, which will become the first Middle East country to host a Formula One race.

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened first hardware store in 1972 after building barns to pay way through college. Midwest-based Menards chain is big rival of Home Depot, Lowe’s: 184 stores, $5.5 billion sales. Indy and Nascar sponsor now tangling with the IRS over back taxes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Boss of Severstal, Russia’s second largest steel company. Son of millworker parents, in the mid-1980s Mordashov went to study economics in Leningrad. Later was named finance director of a steel mill. When the plant’s elderly general director instructed him to buy up shares of the company so it would not fall into the hands of an outsider, Mordashov bought most of the shares himself. Became general director of the company and built it into a conglomerate, acquiring automaker UAZ, coal companies, railroad companies, port facilities, local TV stations and newspapers. Last year he outbid U.S. Steel to buy bankrupt American steel company Rouge Industries for $285 million. A leading proponent of Western-style management training, Mordashov is advocating for Russia’s entry into the WTO.

name: Billionaires
bio: Highly secretive chairman of Samsung Group, best known for its Samsung Electronics. Also is the largest semiconductor/LCD manufacturer in Korea and the world's third-largest mobile phone maker, with a 10% share. Lee is investing heavily in the mobile phone business in hopes of gaining a 25% share by 2010.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of German software giant SAP. The former physicist now focuses on his nonprofit organization, the Heidelberg-based Klaus Tschira Foundation, dedicated to scientific and cultural projects. A small asteroid has been named after this amateur astronomer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former metals trader survived the gangster wars in the aluminum industry. In 2000, at age 31, assumed control of Russian Aluminum, the country’s dominant producer. His holding company, Basic Element, now owns 75% of Russian Aluminum (Roman Abramovich’s Millhouse Capital has the rest), automobile manufacturer GAZ, aircraft manufacturer Aviacor, insurance company Ingosstrakh, other interests. Deripaska feels secure about his property in Russia; instead of liquidating assets, like Abramovich, he is investing heavily in expanding his Russian business empire. Married into family of former President Yeltsin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited fortune in Wal-Mart stock from father, Bud Walton (d. 1995), early business partner and brother of Wal-Mart founder Sam Walton. Husband Stan (see) made his fortune in real estate, including shopping centers anchored by Wal-Mart stores. Big landowner: recently purchased 500,000-acre spread in British Columbia formerly owned by WorldCom’s Bernie Ebbers. Also owns pro basketball’s Denver Nuggets, hockey’s Colorado Avalanche and a stake in football’s St. Louis Rams.

name: Billionaires
bio: The drugstore king. His Schlecker 13,300-store chain represents 70% of all drugstores in Germany. Facing a saturated market, Schlecker is looking to expand in Denmark, Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. Runs the $8.2 billion (sales) company with the help of wife Christa, children Lars and Meike. A tough businessman, he has a reputation for squeezing value from every penny to maintain the low prices—even manning stores with a minimum of personnel and lowering promised salaries for new employees.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ukrainian-born oil baron studied at  Moscow Institute of Transportation Engineering in 1970s. Went into business in 1988, trading personal computers; next year teamed up with former classmate who had immigrated to U.S. Led Russia’s first successful hostile takeover in 1994, when his Renova firm took control of the Vladimir Tractor Factory and installed a Russian-born Harvard M.B.A. to run it. Later bought medium-size aluminum smelters and bauxite mines and united them into $1 billion (sales) Sual Holding in 1996; now selling 25% stake to foreign investment group. But Vekselberg made the bulk of his fortune when he teamed up with Mikhail Fridman’s Alfa Group to take over TNK, Russia’s third-largest oil company. Last year TNK merged with the Russian operations of BP. In February bought the Forbes Fabergé collection for an undisclosed sum and promised to return it to Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: With father Stephen (see), co-owner of engineering and construction giant Bechtel Group. Caught flak after receiving $680 million contract to rebuild Iraq, but it’s only a small slice of the business. Other recent contracts: a $4.3 billion petrochemical complex in southern China, a $1.1 billion aluminum smelter in Bahrain, a $1.4 billion expansion of King Abdulaziz Airport in Jidda, Saudi Arabia.

name: Billionaires
bio: With son Riley (see), co-owner of engineering giant Bechtel Group caught flak after receiving $680 million contract to rebuild Iraq, but it’s only a small slice of the business. Other recent contracts: a $4.3 billion petrochemical complex in southern China, a $1.1 billion aluminum smelter in Bahrain, a $1.4 billion expansion of King Abdulaziz Airport in Jidda, Saudi Arabia.

name: Billionaires
bio: India’s economic revival benefitted Birla’s $6 billion (revenues) global commodities group. Stock prices of flagship Grasim, a fiber and cement company, and aluminium maker Hindalco surged. Birla expanded metals business by acquiring two Australian copper mines. Agreed to swap his 15% stake in engineering giant Larsen & Toubro for a controlling interest in its cement business to become India’s largest cement manufacturer. Birla’s Idea Cellular, a three-way partnership with Tata and AT&T, bought Escotel, a telecom services provider for $256 million, winning out over fellow billionaire Sunil Mittal. Along with wife, Neerja, launched the Sarala Birla Academy, a boarding school for boys named after his grandmother.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of medical equipment manufacturer Cook Group saw his $3 billion buyout offer from Guidant flatline after the company’s innovative drug-coated stent delivered underwhelming results. Breaking up made easier with $50 million payout from Guidant to terminate the merger. Cook Group manufactures thousands of products for medical industry, including catheters and stents. Cook Biotech recently developed new wound dressings using pig intestine tissue.

name: Billionaires
bio: The fortunes of this Harvard Business School graduate are soaring: His Malaysian-based satellite TV service provider orchestrated a successful initial public offering in October 2003, adding another $1 billion to his net worth. His mobile phone service provider Maxis Communications continues to perform well, much to the delight of investors. Also controls racetrack betting and lottery systems in Malaysia via Tanjong Public Ltd.

name: Billionaires
bio:
One of four brothers, Sulaiman owns the largest personal stake in the family’s Al Rajhi Banking and & Investment Corp., which operates under Islamic principles, paying no interest on deposits. He’s also the most active of the brothers, acting as the bank’s chairman and managing director. Both Al Rajhi and the bank have been named in the trillion-dollar lawsuit filed by families of victims of the September 11 attacks, accused of financing terrorist activities. The bank denies the charges. Al Rajhi also boasts his country&#39s largest poultry farm, a building-materials business and real estate. He reportedly has fathered at least 23 children.

from 2004 bio:
Sulaiman bin Abdul Al Rajhi
The man: Chairman and managing director of Al Rajhi Banking & Investment Corp., which operates under Islamic principles, paying no interest on deposits. The fortune: One of four brothers, he has the most active role in the banking empire and the biggest personal stake. Other holdings with family include country&#39s biggest poultry farm, a building-materials business and real estate. He reportedly has at least 23 children. Passions: Farming.

name: Billionaires
bio: With younger brother Ronald (see), controls the cosmetics concern started by mother, Estee in 1946. Leonard was chief executive until 1999; now serves as chairman of the board. Today Estee Lauder dominates the prestige cosmetics industry with such brands as Estee Lauder, Clinique, M.A.C., Aveda, Bobbi Brown and Stila. Son William takes over as CEO this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: The unusually reclusive twins found themselves in the media spotlight after their offer to buy Conrad Black’s controlling stake in media empire Hollinger International was challenged by the board. With the deal languishing in the courts, the Barclays have time to focus on their recent acquisitions, U.K. retailer Littlewoods and mail-order operations of the GUS group (a major shareholder of Burberry). Other holdings include London’s Ritz hotel and casino and Scottish newspapers—all managed from the island tax haven of Jersey. Both are married, and Sir David’s son, Aidan, 48, is the heir apparent to the growing Barclay empire.

name: Billionaires
bio: The merry widow. Became a widow in her mid-40s, when her husband, Helmut Horten, founder of the eponymous German department store chain, died in 1987. Lived in tax-haven Switzerland for more than 30 years but was apparently homesick. In early 2002 returned to Vienna, where she now lives in a luxurious penthouse. Also has a home in Lyford Cay in the Bahamas. Her 315-foot yacht, Carinthia VII, is said to be one of the most magnificent yachts afloat today. Press reports link her to ex-British banker Jonathan Bevan. Said to love hunting, and collects modern art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took over family’s Kaiser-Francis Oil in 1969. Oil and gas exploration remain driving force behind empire, but other fortunes in banking, real estate, venture capital. Donates money to education, poverty programs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Star Wars creator wrapped up filming in Australia for the next and final installment of his sci-fi series; movie set for spring 2005 release. Other engine, special effects shop Industrial Light & Magic, worked on last summer’s hits Pirates of the Caribbean, The Hulk, Terminator 3.

name: Billionaires
bio: His $2.8 billion (sales) tour outfit, Globus & Cosmos, finally rebounding somewhat after Sept. 11 attacks, bookings are up this year. Founded in 1928 by father, Antonio, with a single boat that ferried tourists around Lake Lugano. President Sergio has been with the company for 50 years. Loves expensive toys: has a helicopter and a yacht (Lady Marina) and recently bought himself a $600,000 Mercedes Maybach. Son Fabio is CEO of Monarch Travel, the family’s no-frills airline. Son Paolo, who was CEO of Globus’ American arm, Group Voyagers, died in February.

name: Billionaires
bio: Canada’s generic drug kingpin controls publicly traded Barr Labs, as well as closely held Apotex. Highly private Sherman retired from Barr and pocketed $250 million from share sales last year alone. Apotex claimed a big legal victory against GlaxoSmithKline in March of 2003 when it won the right to produce a generic version of supersuccessful antidepressant Paxil. Expected to soon manufacture generic equivalent of AIDS med Retrovir-AZT. Apotex considering selling off more of its 80% stake in publicly traded Cangene, another Canadian generic drug maker, to unlock value.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former fighter pilot started out leasing cars from Cadillac body shop 1957. Named company after his WWII aircraft carrier, U.S.S. Enterprise. Business took off in 1970s; became nation’s largest rental fleet after courts forced insurance companies to pay for replacement rentals. Son Andrew now driving $6.5 billion (sales) company.

name: Billionaires
bio: This savvy banker sold most of his Banco Real to ABN Amro for $2.1 billion in 1998. But last year Brazilian papers reported that his former son-in-law sued him, claiming he’s owed a bigger piece of the sale proceeds.  Faria has built up the remaining assets of Banco Real into Banco Alfa, Brazil’s 19th-largest bank. Other holdings: hotels, land and a chain of do-it-yourself stores.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner John Sall (see), co-owner of SAS Institute, world’s largest privately held software company (sales: $1.2 billion). Firm benefiting as Silicon Valley rivals Oracle and PeopleSoft are engaged in brutal takeover battle. Techie employees kept happy with precrash perks like Olympic-size swimming pool, 35-hour workweek, free soda.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth generation of a Swiss-German industrial fortune. The Spanish insider trading case, which forced him to step down from the top post of cementmaker Holcim (he still controls a 23.6% stake and has a seat on the board), is finally over after a $1.9 million fine and a public apology. Now he can focus on entrepreneurial ventures and building his wine business, including the Cuvaison and Chapel Hill labels.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ohio State law school dropout opened first Limited outlet 1963 with $5,000 loan. Now 5,300 stores generate over $8 billion in sales. Current brands: Victoria&#39s Secret, Bath & Body Works, Express, Express Men&#39s (Structure), Lerner New York, Limited Stores, White Barn Candle Co., Henri Bendel. Spinoffs: Abercrombie & Fitch 1998, Limited Too 1999. Art enthusiast Wexner bought and donated $45 million “Nude on a Black Armchair” by Picasso.

name: Billionaires
bio: Publicity-shy Gou (sometimes known as Kuo) runs electronic maker Hon Hai Precision, known as Foxconn Electronics in the US. Average sales over the last five years have increased an impressive 62% annually. And it's not over. Gou reportedly raised $850 million  overseas to build manufacturing plants in Mexico, Brazil, India and the Czech Republic. Like his counterpart Barry Lam, Gou is also moving full throttle into LCD-panel manufacturing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Emerged the victor in his long quest to oust older brother Günter from the family-owned Tchibo Holding, one of Germany’s largest retail groups. Last August he and two brothers bought out Günter and sister, Daniela, for an estimated $5 billion. With the dispute resolved, the remaining family members faced no resistance bidding for a larger stake in Beiersdorf, maker of Nivea products. Tchibo now owns nearly half, assuring that the company, also courted by L’Oréal and Procter & Gamble, remains in German hands. Word is Michael and brother Wolfgang, whose each own 34% of Tchibo, have emerged as the key players in the business. Brother Joachim with his 15% share apparently plays a lesser role

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Hong Leong Group Singapore, a conglomerate with more than 300 companies, including 12 listed ones. His City Developments is a leading real estate developer in Singapore, and his Millenium & Copthorne runs a chain of hotels including the Millenium Hilton Hotel in New York, which was damaged in the World Trade Center attack. Malaysian cousin Quek Leng Chan is also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Bud Walton (d. 1995), brother and business partner of Wal-Mart founder Sam Walton. Nancy split fortune in Wal-Mart stock with sister Ann Kroenke (see). With husband, Bill, owns pro hockey’s St. Louis Blues. Breeds horses on 350-acre Crown Center Farms.

name: Billionaires
bio: Main holding, pulp manufacturer CMPC, appears to be getting back on track. After a 50% profit drop in 2001, eked out a modest profit increase in 2002 and expects to report similar numbers for 2003. Plans to expand wood pulp business this year. Also has interests in Chilean banks, real estate and shipping ports.

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with brothers Bruce and John, surviving sons of cable investor John Elroy McCaw (youngest son, Keith, 48, died in 2002). Brothers inherited company after father’s death in 1969, made big bet on cellular; sold to AT&T in 1993 for $11.5 billion. Siblings remain tight, but independent. Craig struggles with investments in Nextel, satellite Internet service Teledesic. Bruce is a racecar enthusiast. John owns pro hockey’s Vancouver Canucks.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of electronics retailer Best Buy started with stereo store in Minnesota in 1966. Now, 566 Best Buy stores. Unloaded unprofitable Musicland subsidiary (Sam Goody and Suncoast) last year just before lawsuit alleging deceptive sales practices at Goody and other outlets. Stepped down as CEO in June 2002; remains chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Johnson Electric, one of the world’s leading manufacturer of mini motors. Founded in 1959 by his parents to make motors for toy boats. These days the motors are found in antilock braking systems, power drills, seat adjusters and blood-pressure pumps. Wang holds a master’s degree in electrical engineering from Purdue University in Indiana. Mother Koo Yik Chun sits on the board as honorary chairman, sister Winnie is vice chairman of the group and brother Richard heads global marketing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Russia’s largest oil company, Lukoil. As acting minister of fuel and energy in the last Soviet government in 1991, cobbled together oil giant Lukoil out of some of the best Russian oil properties, then muscled in on a big deal in the Caspian Sea, bought refineries in eastern Europe and the Getty gas station chain in the U.S. After a few difficult years, in which Lukoil underperformed its Russian rivals, the company is back on the growth track. Alekperov is in good standing with President Vladimir Putin; Lukoil has a good chance of developing one of Iraq’s biggest oilfields (under an old contract signed under Saddam Hussein), recently got permission to develop an oilfield in Saudi Arabia and is moving ahead with plans to export Russian oil directly to the U.S.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns nearly 19% of Metro AG, one of the world’s largest retailers. At 80, this widower keeps himself busy. He’s building a 16,000-square-meter luxury development in a tony neighborhood in central Berlin. The upscale complex will include two hotels, office space, restaurants and shops. Also actively promotes Beisheim Holding Schweiz AG, an Internet and tech company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bronfman clan still pinning some hope on music curing Vivendi-induced hangover. In November son Edgar Jr., along with LBO titan Thomas Lee, agreed to purchase Warner Music Group for $2.6 billion. Move came months after failed attempt to buy back Vivendi assets family had sold to French utility and entertainment giant in 2000. Father Samuel made fortune selling Seagram’s Canadian whiskey in the U.S. during Prohibition. Brother Edgar took over spirits business 1971, diversified: big DuPont stake 1981; bought Tropicana 1988. Handed reins to Edgar Jr., who quickly went Hollywood. Unloaded DuPont stake for shares of Time Warner; sold juice business to finance purchase of MCA/Universal. Sour mix: with box office sales flat and music business in disarray, sold everything to Vivendi for $34 billion in 2000.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned his father’s dust removal business into publicly listed GEA, a process and thermal engineering firm. In 1999 sold his stake to engineering company MG Technologies for $1 billion in cash and stock and retired to tax haven Switzerland to run Luserve AG, a financial consulting firm. Still keeps an eye on the family business. Last April he upped his stake in MG to nearly 21%, becoming the company’s largest shareholder. Then ousted his nemesis, MG’s chairman, with whom he had a very public dispute. Now sits on supervisory board where he will no doubt continue to exert influence. Other interests: He reportedly owns Fregate Island, a luxury paradise in the Seychelles, as well as a yacht which sails in regattas in New Zealand.

name: Billionaires
bio: From making bicycle parts in Ludhiana, a trading town in North India, Mittal is now India’s leading telecom pioneer and the first private operator to launch cellular services in the country. His $1.1 billion (revenues) Bharti group runs country’s largest GSM-based mobile phone service. Mittal has his hands full battling arch rivals, the Ambanis of Reliance and the Tata group. Biggest asset is family’s stakein flagship Bharti Tele-Ventures, in which Singapore Telecom and Warburg Pincus have jointly invested nearly $1 billion. The stock, first listed two years ago, soared 376% last year, propelling Mittal into the billionaire ranks. A believer in lucky charms, Mittal travels in his ten-year-old Mercedes to important business meetings.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Israeli brothers have stepped up their shipping activities, recently buying the other half of shipping concern Zim Navigation from the Israeli government (they already owned half). Brothers share stake in cruise line Royal Caribbean with Chicago’s Pritzker family. Planned merger with P&O Princess was scuttled by rival bid from Carnival Corp. No harm done. Royal Caribbean stock up 230% over last year thanks, in part, to increased bookings. Monaco-based Sammy controls shipping assets, while brother Yuli runs real estate, banking and tech operations from Tel Aviv. Sammy, an avid art collector, boasts the world’s largest collection of Marc Chagall originals.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former talent agent runs nation’s largest Spanish-language TV network. With partners spent $550 million for Univision in 1992; his 16% stake now is worth $1.3 billion. Also radio: last year paid $3.5 billion for Spanish-language powerhouse Hispanic Broadcasting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Corporate lawyer joined dad’s Tana Oil & Gas in 1972; sold production units to Texaco in 1989, exploration division to Unocal. Bought luxury hospitality chain Omni Hotels 1996; now 40 hotels throughout North America. Continues investing in oil and gas, mostly exploration in the Gulf of Mexico.

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of $14 billion (sales) Dogus conglomerate, which brought Discovery Channel to Turkey in 2003. Weathered three-year restructuring effort at his Tansas supermarket chain, long enough to attract $30 million from British investors. Established a motorcar racing organization in 2003. Turkey’s closure of overextended banks helped increase market share and value of his Garanti Bank, one of only six financial institutions approved by the government to sell private pensions. Established Ottoman Bank Museum to enliven the historic Galata and Pera districts of Istanbul. The subject of a Harvard Business School case study, Sahenk loves snapping black-and-white photos with his prized Leica camera.

name: Billionaires
bio: Practically nothing is known about these two brothers, other than that they live in Switzerland (Rainer in Luzern and Michael in Zurich) and own 18.84% of giant retailer Metro, as do Otto Beisheim and the Haniel family.

name: Billionaires
