bio: Austrian real estate baron. After World War II earned a living as a jazz pianist (stage name Charlie Walker). Later founded Billa, one of Austria’s most successful retail store chains. Sold it in 1996 and invested proceeds in Austrian real estate, amassing a portfolio of high-end buildings, including four painstakingly restored palaces in Vienna, the Radisson and Europa hotels in Salzburg and the Hotel Lasalle in Vienna, a couple of sleek office towers and the historic  building that houses the Vienna Stock Exchange. One pet project is the renovation of the Cafe Central, an old Viennese coffee house now a concert cafe, where jazz-lover Wlaschek often hangs out.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third son of Texas oilman Perry Bass (see). Broke out on his own in 1983 when father handed business to eldest brother, Sid. Investments include drill-rig supplier Lone Star Technologies, railroader Florida East Coast. Most recent move: $700 million (including debt) purchase of troubled drug-store chain Duane Reade.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth son of coffee magnate Max Herz and wife, Ingeburg. He and his brothers finally succeeded in pushing older brother Günter and their sister, Daniela, out of their family firm, Tchibo Holding, after buying them out for an estimated $5 billion. Sits on the supervisory board, along with brothers Michael and Joachim. His 34% stake establishes him as one of Tchibo’s key players.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Rupert Sr., founded early mutual fund outfit Franklin Distributors 1947. With brother, Rupert, took over, expanded Franklin Resources by adding Templeton Funds 1992, Fiduciary Trust 2001. Today $343 billion assets under management. December: Company suspends three employees following federal investigation into alleged-market timing; Massachusetts filed suit against Franklin in February. Charles: Yale grad, former Army lieutenant, current chairman and CEO.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brother, Willi, and sister, Isolde, took the lead over siblings Hans Jr., Markus and Hubert in running the diversified family business after their father died in 1993. They’ve managed to grow the core construction crane unit in a lagging European building market as well as promote other products, including aircraft control systems, refrigerators and hotels. Germany’s Chancellor Gerhard Schröder was at the groundbreaking ceremony of their latest plant in the Baltic coast town of Rostock.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth generation of a Swiss-German industrial fortune. Built his portfolio through strategic investments and divestitures from selling construction materials maker Eternit (to brother Thomas) to providing startup funds to the precursor of Swatch. Retired from all corporate and board responsibilities last year to focus full-time on his philanthropic interests. Donated all shares of his company, Grupo Nueva, the equivalent of over $1 billion, to the Viva Trust, which will manage the company and fund Schmidheiny’s not-for-profit, Avina. Schmidheiny believes this corporate-philanthropic association is the future model for sustainable giving.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Bronfman clan is pressing on, hoping music will cure its recent Vivendi-induced hangover. In November nephew Edgar Jr., along with LBO titan Thomas Lee, agreed to purchase Warner Music Group for $2.6 billion, just months after failed attempt to buy back Vivendi assets. Father Samuel made fortune selling Seagram’s Canadian whiskey in the U.S. during Prohibition. Brother Edgar took over spirits business in 1971, turning it into a well-respected, diversified conglomerate. Handed reins to Edgar Jr., who quickly went Hollywood. Unloaded DuPont stake for shares of Time Warner; sold Tropicana juice business to finance purchase of MCA/Universal. Sour mix: with box office sales flat and music business in disarray, sold everything to Vivendi for $34 billion in 2000. After helping oust Vivendi chief Jean-Marie Messier in 2002, Charles cut his losses. Vivendi stake believed to be worth only $400 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: World’s largest private chemical company coming back from brink. After high gas prices and low demand ravaged his highly leveraged business, Huntsman negotiated debt with creditors, gaving up 49% equity in the process. Son Peter now runs the family business, while son Jon Jr. running on Republican ticket for governor of Utah. Cancer survivor Huntsman gave $225 million to form Huntsman Cancer Institute.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Husband, Bronson Ingram, inherited father’s oil and barge empire 1963. Added distribution business: books, computers, videotapes. Martha inherited fortune after Bronson’s death. Took Ingram Micro public a year later. Privately held Ingram Industries run by 
three sons. Active arts supporter in Nashville.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owner and honorary chairman of $30 billion (sales) Ito-Yokado retailing group, which includes more than 10,000 7-Elevens in Japan and the U.S. Also has 177 Yokado superstores and about 1,000 other shops (department stores, restaurants, specialty shops, supermarkets and superstores). Managed to eke out only a modest sales and profit increase last year, reflecting consumer uncertainty. Ito built all this from a small family clothing shop.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive of Lego, Billund, Denmark-based toymaker, since 1979. Founded by his grandfather Ole Kirk Christiansen in 1932, based on the philosophy that play is essential to a child’s development. The words “leg godt” mean “play well” in Danish. Lego is now one of the world’s largest toy manufacturers, known for its colorful blocks. But this past year was no fun. Facing stiff competition, the company expects to post the worst year in its 72-year history, with a pretax loss of $216 million on sales of $1.3 billion.  The privately held group fired its chief operating officer in January, turning those additional responsibilities over to Kristiansen.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir of John D. Rockefeller, grain merchant who transformed $4,000 investment into Standard Oil. Dominated the oil market, until broken up in 1911 landmark antitrust case. Son John Jr. moved money into real estate, built Rockefeller Center. David went on to head up Chase Manhattan, serving as chairman from 1969 to 1981; also headed up the Council on Foreign Relations 1970 to 1985. Last year published autobiography Memoir. Currently developing organic agricultural operations on farm north of New York City.

name: Billionaires
bio: With David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg (see both), owns Hollywood hit factory DreamWorks SKG. Concentrates on making movies, not meetings: “I get a headache when they start talking about refinancing and things like that.” Unmatched record as director: Jaws, E.T., Jurassic Park, Schindler’s List, Saving Private Ryan, etc. Next directorial effort: The Terminal, air traveler’s nightmare starring Tom Hanks.

name: Billionaires
bio: There’s no escaping him. His name appears in neon lights atop his casinos, on the sides of his personal aircraft and on labels of bottled water. Even on television, where his hit reality show, The Apprentice, is being readied for a second season. But for The Donald, it’s still all about real estate: over 18 million square feet of prime Manhattan office and residential space, including 40 Wall Street, Trump World Tower, and Trump International Hotel. Estimated net worth (“It’s low, but you guys like it that way”) sure to blossom as construction marches on at West Side rail yard development, 80-acre site bought in 1985 for $80 million. Avid golfer (4 handicap), owns courses in Westchester County, N.Y. and Palm Beach; applying final touches on Fazio-designed course in Bedminster, N.J.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Hubert Burda Media Holding, which celebrated its 100th birthday last year, publishes over 235 magazine titles. Despite miserable advertising climate, sales have remained even ($2.3 billion in 2002). Investments in new titles are balanced by continued success of business, mass market and womens  magazines like Focus, Bunte and Freundin. Burda, who studied art history, archeology and sociology at Ludwig-Maximilian University in Munich, continues his support of the arts, sponsoring the Herman-Lenz Prize for German Literature and a media center at Ben-Gurion University in Israel.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Charles Gerald John Cadogan
The U.K.’s second-richest landowner enjoyed the title of Viscount Chelsea before inheriting the mantle of earl in 1997. Last year he fought to stop the development of a luxury building on land that his grandfather had sold with the stipulation that it be used for the “benefit of the working class.” A judge ruled that while the term “working class” still exists, the earl did not have any title to the land because it was sold by a company that has since dissolved. Meanwhile, the earl has reportedly been busy with the conversion of an old church in Chelsea into a 900-seat concert hall, another jewel to add to his bulging portfolio.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bought his father’s one-route Ontario bus company for a dollar in 1951; eventually built into Power Corp., a $14 billion (sales) financial services and communications giant. A Power Corp. consortium bought an indirect 25% stake in media giant Bertelsmann in early 2001. Also owns Investors Group, Canada’s largest mutual fund group. Power Corp has seen its stock rise 40% this year. Holdings include everything from media and financial services to waste services and specialty mineral companies. While sons Andre and Paul Jr. run the company, Paul Sr. collects Canadian art and hunts birds at his private estate in Quebec.

name: Billionaires
bio: Friends since the early 1940s: duo joined military together after high school; opened drive-in eatery; than Amway. Amway, reorganized as Alticor in 2000, now distributes more than $4.9 billion worth of personal care and home products in 80 countries. Richard: heart transplant recipient, owner pro basketball’s Orlando Magic, recently donated $20 million to help build the DeVos Place Convention Center in Grand Rapids, Michigan. Jay: formed the Van Andel Institute for cancer research, education.

name: Billionaires
bio: The notoriously press-shy heir to the Campbell Soup fortune fled the U.S. for Ireland in 1994 to avoid taxes. Besides a modest red brick home in Dublin, Dorrance boasts a pied-a-terre in the Bahamas and one in Wyoming. Resurfaced in the early 1990s to unsuccessfully pressure Wyoming legislators to legalize game ranching for native and exotic wildlife. The bid failed, and with it his plans to raise imported sheep, boar, elk and wolf.

name: Billionaires
bio: President of Promise, one of four major Japanese consumer-loan firms. Amid the consistently high rate of personal bankruptcies, company expects loan losses to grow by 24% and profits to drop 23%. Donated $1 billion to an agriculturalCK research foundation in a deserted area in northern Japan. Also funds Jinnai Cultural center in Peru, but so far shows no signs of expanding his business into South America.

name: Billionaires
bio: Polish-born cook and chambermaid married her boss, Johnson & Johnson heir John Seward Johnson Sr. (d. 1983). After explosive court battle with stepchildren over the estate, “Basia” walked away with over $335 million and a palatial Princeton, N.J. mansion (later turned into a golf clubhouse). Philanthropist and low-profile art collector auctioned off Andrea Mantegna’s “Descent Into Limbo” last year for $28.5 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: The former deli-owner turned shopping mall Midas oversees an $24 billion (assets under management) portfolio of 117 centers on three continents. In December extricated himself from the nettlesome insurance and redevelopment battles surrounding the World Trade Center by selling his 99-year lease on the WTC’s subterranean shopping plaza to the Port Authority of New York & New Jersey for $140 million. (His Westfield Holdings lost an employee at the World Trade Center on Sept. 11.) Lost another battle for U.S. retail space in thwarted hostile takeover bid (with Simon Property) of Taubman Centers’ 21 malls. At the behest of the Aussie government is helping to revive the country’s languishing soccer league.

name: Billionaires
bio: Japan’s leading real estate mogul. Owns and operates more than 80 properties, including hotels, offices, apartments and retail space. Recently signed an agreement with Hilton International to manage Japan&#39s first Conrad hotel in Tokyo, scheduled to open in spring 2005. Estranged brother Minoru, who is no longer on Billionaires’ list because of debts, has been generating a lot of publicity and cash flow with a massive new building complex in central Tokyo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son is rising again. Briefly worth $76 billion in 2000, Son has been on a roller-coaster ride. Things are looking up for the founder and president of Softbank, thanks to an aggressive promotion of a new broadband business in Japan. In turn, Softbank’s stock tripled. Son has mortgaged a portion of his stake. Now setting his sights on the mobile phone industry.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cable news pioneer remains Time Warner’s largest individual shareholder despite dumping 60 million shares last May. Clashed with top brass over his diminished role and dwindling fortune. Less hassle making bison burgers at fledgling restaurant chain, Ted’s Montana Grill. Ardent conservationist, America’s largest landowner.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hungarian immigrant’s family fled Soviet occupation 1958. Studied economics at UCLA but got hooked on flying. Licensed pilot teamed up with Louis and Leslie Gonda (see both) with the idea of buying, leasing planes to airlines. Sold company in 1990 to AIG for stock. Rising AIG shares have since made all three billionaires. Donated $60 million to Smithsonian to build the Udvar-Hazy Center at Virginia&#39s Dulles Airport, an air and space museum that opened in December.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lords over a diversified empire in Mexico that includes the world’s biggest silver producer, owned by his Industrias Peñoles, the successful department store Palacio de Hierro and a major insurance company. His fortunes have risen $800 million in the last two years thanks largely to the strength of his mining operations. Something of a throwback, Bailleres is passionate about bullfighting and horse racing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former bag boy founded investment company Yucaipa 1986; made fortune  buying and selling supermarket chains Fred Meyer, Jurgensen’s, Ralphs. Other holdings: Alliance Entertainment, Occidental Petroleum. September: invested $100 million in Sean "P. Diddy" Combs&#39 Sean Jean clothing line. Reportedly sold stake in Golden State Foods, supplier of food products to McDonald’s, for $110 million in February. Longtime Democratic fundraiser, friends with Bill Clinton and Jesse Jackson.

name: Billionaires
bio: The music world’s most famous recluse is now one of the richest thanks to the $2.7 billion check he got from BMG for his Zomba Recordings, much of which he personally pocketed. The South African-born mogul is the man who benefited most from the teen music craze: Britney Spears, ’N Sync, and the Backstreet Boys all recorded their bubblegum pop for his label. Raised in a middle-class neighborhood in Johannesburg, Calder started out playing bass guitar in local bands, then worked as a scout for EMI records. Formed Zomba in 1971, immigrated to London four years later, the U.S. in 1978.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads New World Development, one of Hong Kong’s leading conglomerates, with more than $2.7 billion in annual revenues. Experienced another tough year: New World Development announced a $619 million loss for the fiscal year ended June 2003. “Economic cycle is just like a ferris wheel,” says Cheng in his letter to his shareholders in 2003. “One needs to go through the lowest point before reaching the peak again.”

name: Billionaires
bio: California real estate syndicator in the 1970s noticed growing demand for self-storage space. Today Public Storage has more than 800,000 self-storage spaces in 80 cities. Stepped down as CEO last November; still chairman. Spends time breeding, racing Thoroughbreds. Paid $900,000 for fourth-place Kentucky Derby finisher Atswhatimtalknbout. “When you are old you tend to look back. In this business you have to look forward into the future.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Eldest son of the second family of Texas wildcatter H.L. Hunt (d. 1974) inherited most of father’s Hunt Oil Co. with three sisters. Expanded the family business while half siblings, led by Bunker Hunt, went bust speculating on silver. Holds big stakes in Canadian natural gas fields; recently making large investments in liquefied natural gas plants in Peru and Yemen.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rough winter for Kellogg: In November charged by NASD with using his personal accounts to illegally trade millions of shares of Thoratec. The "washed" sales allegedly took place in August 2001. Father James C. Kellogg III became partner at investment boutique 1945; became Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, nation’s largest specialist on New York Stock Exchange. Peter took over in 1973; sold company to Goldman Sachs in 2000 for $5.7 billion. Other stakes in laser imaging (Presstek), telecom (CenterSpan Communications), paper (Mercer International).

name: Billionaires
bio: Started designing ties in 1967; an entire fashion empire followed. Credited for marketing fashion as lifestyle choice: “My clothes are always visions of what I believe in.” Big believer in brand extension. Today Ralph Lauren, Polo lines encompass menswear, women’s wear, kids’ clothes, luggage, fabrics, home furnishings, fragrances. 2003 sales: $2.4 billion. Eldest son, Andrew, an aspiring actor. Daughter, Dylan, runs Manhattan candy store. Youngest son, David, Polo vice president.

name: Billionaires
bio: This supersecretive construction tycoon is the largest individual shareholder in Tata Sons, holding company of the $11.2 billion Tata conglomerate. His 18.4% stake, valued at $1.9 billion, is up almost 30%; should be worth more once Tata Consultancy Services, India’s largest software services firm, lists this year. Despite his large stake, Mistry has been a passive investor in the Tata group. One of his two sons is likely to join the Tata Sons’ board when Mistry, who turns 75 this June, retires. The family’s lossmaking online lottery venture was recently shut down. Mistry is building an office complex for software firms next to his stud farm outside Mumbai.

name: Billionaires
bio: Following the Tsai brothers’ decision to split the family’s financial group back in the late 1980s, Tsai Wan Tsai heads Fubon Financial Holdings. Tsai has taken a backseat to his U.S.-educated sons, Richard and Daniel, who have been trying to increase Fubon’s competitiveness. A recent attempt to acquire Hong Kong-based International Bank of Asia as a stepping-stone to China has reportedly met some opposition by Taiwan’s regulatory body. Brother Tsai Wan Lin, also a billionaire, overseas Cathay Financial Holdings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Much-celebrated fashion designer. A big concern these days is finding a successor who can oversee his $1.8 billion (2002 sales) private company. Spent two years in medical school before dropping out in 1957 to accept a job as a department store buyer. Also owns his own Nobu restaurant and a night club in Milan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Every other German reads a magazine published by his Verlagsgruppe Bauer, the $2.2 billion (sales) company founded by Bauer’s grandfather in 1875. Suffered less exposure in recent years to advertising slump thanks to TV-programming pubs—75% of company revenues—which are generally less dependent on ad sales. Among the popular German titles: a TV guide called Maxi, and Praline, a racy girlie mag; in the U.S., titles include Woman’s World, Soap Opera Update and Soaps in Depth. Despite stabilized revenues, an otherwise frustrating year for Bauer. First he was outbid by Power Rangers creator Haim Saban for the media assets of former billionaire Leo Kirch. No small defeat, the assets included Europe’s largest film library and about half of Germany’s largest TV broadcaster, ProSiebenSat1. He was then licked again for Berlin daily Tagesspiegel, which was sold to an insider. No comment from Bauer, who seldom grants interviews to the press.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sir Richard’s antics keep his name in the news. And so do his ever ambitious plans. Virgin Mobile UK, pay-as-you-go cell phone company, may go public later this year. Optimistic analysts say it could be valued at $1.8 billion; a junk bond offering is another option. Also in the works for the high-school-dropout-cum-billionaire: A low-cost, high-frills domestic U.S. airline carrier to compete with JetBlue and Southwest, and a New Jersey spa at an estate that was once home to Morocco’s King Hassan II.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of Internet portal Yahoo met partner Jerry Yang (see) in 1989 while pursuing master’s degrees in electrical engineering at Stanford. Both became billionaires while working on their Ph.D.s. Landed 112,000 users in five months. Sold minority interest to Sequoia Capital; took public in 1996. Survived tech implosion while turning the business over to adults: Business is run by former Warner Bros. chief Terry Semel.

name: Billionaires
bio: President of Funai Electric, a medium-size audiovisual equipment manufacturer. Makes most of its low-price televisions and DVD players in China and then ships them to North America and Europe. North American retailers such as Wal-Mart account for 70% of sales. Earnings up 49% in past year on strong demand.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of cable system operator sold it twice: first in 1996 to US West, then in 1999 to AT&T. Got cash, AT&T stock and a seat on the board, but took big hit when cable stocks fizzled. Still invests via Boston firm Pilot House. Active fundraiser for alma mater Amherst.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rupert, with older brother Charles (see), runs Franklin Resources. Father, Rupert Sr., founded early mutual fund outfit Franklin Distributors 1947. Brothers took over, expanded Franklin Resources by adding Templeton Funds 1992, Fiduciary Trust 2001. Today $343 billion assets under management. December: Company suspends three employees following federal investigation into alleged market timing; Massachusetts filed suit against Franklin last in February. Charles: Yale grad, former Army lieutenant, current chairman and CEO. Rupert: Washington & Lee grad, onetime Marine, assists as vice chairman. Charles’ eldest son, Gregory, serves as co-president.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner, Arthur Blank, founded hardware juggernaut Home Depot in 1978 after getting axed from now-defunct Handy Dan chain. Took public three years later. Today Home Depot has 1,500 stores, $58 billion in sales. Marcus now retired but remains the largest individual shareholder, financing $200 million aquarium in downtown Atlanta.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of German immigrant now trying to save family legacy: Son Edward’s Canary Capital Partners hedge fund set off recent mutual fund scandal, paid $40 million to settle investigation into illegal trading practices. Family empire focusing on real estate in recent years: sold Village Voice weekly, Hartz Mountain pet supply business started by father in 1926. Owns 35 million square feet of office, retail space in New Jersey, posh Soho Grand and Tribeca Grand hotels in Manhattan. Chairman of NYC’s Homes for the Homeless.

name: Billionaires
bio: After two failed attempts at starting businesses, founded Keyence, now a leading maker of sensor and control equipment. Remains chairman. Stock price rose 200% this year due to strong demand for sensors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Aggressive banker bought rival Singapore bank Overseas Union Bank Ltd. in 2002. The move transformed his United Overseas Bank Group into the country’s biggest bank. Raised $1 billon from a bond issue last year, which will likely be used to expand into other parts of Southeast Asia.

name: Billionaires
bio: “Gravedancer” built real estate empire in 1990s buying distressed properties. Split portfolio into three public REITs that now pay him $45 million in dividends annually. Vulture instinct resurfacing: Through his trailer-park REIT, Manufactured Home Communities, almost nabbed undervalued rival Chateau Communities on the cheap; walked when price heated up.

name: Billionaires
bio: With husband Donald (see) founded Gap clothing chain 1969, took it public 1976. Added Banana Republic 1983, GapKids 1986, BabyGap 1990, Old Navy 1994, GapBody 1998. New chief, Paul Pressler (recruited from Disney), runs day-to-day business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Suffered plunging fortunes in January when Adecco, the Swiss employment agency of which he owns 18%, announced it was investigating possible accounting errors. Adecco stock tumbled 35% that weekend. Matters got uglier when Klaus Jacobs, another billionaire owner of Adecco, publicly dissed Chief Jerome Caille, Foriel-Destezet's godson. Foriel-Destezet, who lives in London, kept mum. Partial vindication came in February when Adecco declared the accounting errors would be insignificant, lifting the stock halfway where it was before the accounting imbroglio.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Swiss resident heads the Gerling Academy for Risk Research, a think tank that studies the industrial world’s impact on the environment. What he’s not thinking as much about: Gerling Konzern, one of the worlds’ largest reinsurers, a business he inherited from his father. Having lost patience, partner Deutsche Bank pulled out last August, leaving Gerling with 94% of the firm, in the throes of a restructuring. Gerling’s future role is yet to be determined—his interest seems to be elsewhere.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of business titan J. Paul Getty (d. 1976) sold family’s Getty Oil to Texaco for $10 billion in 1986. Now committed composer: his Joan and the Bells recently recorded by Russian National Orchestra. Business mostly a pleasant diversion. Investment vehicle ReFlow buys illiquid shares from mutual funds; PlumpJack companies include Squaw Valley resort and cult Napa Valley winery. Packages $170-a-bottle wine in screwcaps, citing scientific evidence they’re better than cork. High-profile patron of the arts in California. Passionate baseball fan often seen at San Francisco Giants games.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Pixar animation shop produced blockbuster Finding Nemo. But that wasn't good enough for Disney Chief Michael Eisner, who was unwilling to give in to Jobs' demands for a new distribution agreement. Don't expect the Apple Computer avatar to have any problems finding a new partner to distribute Pixar product.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Alfred Lerner, furniture salesman who invested earnings in Cleveland-area real estate, banking. Bought control of Equitable Bancorp 1981, merged with Maryland National 1989; spun off MBNA 1991. After father&#39s death in 2002, Randy got pro football’s Browns franchise, which dad had returned to Cleveland in 1999; daughter Nancy Lerner Beck (see) inherited stake in Maryland REIT Town and Country Trust.

name: Billionaires
bio: Under his aegis, Hong Leong Group Malaysia was transformed into one of the leading financial conglomerates in Asia. His Guoco Group, traded on the Hong Kong stock exchange, is a leading real estate developer and financial services firm with operations throughout Asia. Quek oversees the Malaysian operations while cousin Kwek oversees the Singaporean. Family businesses are linked via interlocking ownership stakes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Farmer’s son restored failing Bank of North Carolina before merging with NCNB 1982. Renamed NationsBank, now Bank of America, following merger with Bank America. Former president of University of North Carolina controls over 16 million shares. Family involved on all fronts: wife, Meredith, sits on board; daughter, Anna, guiding venture capital firm Wakefield Group; son-in-law chief of construction products manufacturer National Gypsum. Spends spare time tinkering with grandfather clocks.

name: Billionaires
bio: On his 18th birthday became the sole heir of a royal family fortune that includes extensive landholdings, real estate, castles, works of art and businesses. (His illustrious family held a monopoly over imperial communications between Vienna and the Hapsburg empire for over 300 years.) With high school behind him, the tall (6’4”) prince took his turn at obligatory German military service at a base in Baden Wurttemberg last fall.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bouygues, 52, is chief of Bouygues Telecom, a television-telecom-construction company that has handily outmaneuvered bigger rivals like France Telecom. Profits up 23% on flat revenues last year as cell phone business began to throw off serious cash.  Sunny outlook in the construction unit, which recently secured new contracts for a Peugeot plant in Slovakia and a performing arts center in Hong Kong. Martin is married to a Franco-American woman, a native of Baton Rouge, La.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive of Mediolanum SpA, life insurance and fund management company he cofounded. Longtime business ally of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, he is the largest shareholder in Mediolanum, followed by the politician. Also serves on board of prominent Italian investment bank Mediobanca. Enjoys mountain biking.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs $1 billion (revenues) Godrej group and is one of Bombay’s biggest landowners. Family’s 3,500 acre suburban estate is worth $900 million. Godre, 51, paid $6 million for Upstream, a small call-center firm in the U.S., and is eyeing more acquisitions overseas. The group set up a family council to groom younger family members. Donated $1 million to establish environment center in the southern city of Hyderabad to help Indian companies become environment-conscious. Wife, Parmeshwar, has teamed up with pal Richard Gere to raise funds for children with AIDS.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2001 Citigroup bought Banamex, the big Mexican bank Hernandez was running at the time, for $12.5 billion. Hernandez pocketed almost $2 billion. Still chairs the Banamex board and retains a seat on Citigroup’s board. He&#39s also chairman of Mexico&#39s National Museum of History and spends his free time fixing up old cotton haciendas in Mexico&#39s Yucatan peninsula. Recently returned from a year-long sabbatical that took him to London, Rome, Tokyo, and Beijing.

name: Billionaires
bio: President and majority shareholder of publicly traded Kühne & Nagel, one of the world’s premier transport and logistics groups. Transferred the company (and his own estate) to Switzerland. Married with no children, he’s established a foundation which looks as if it will assume the estate upon his death. Hobbies include opera, tennis and skiing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mother, Estée Lauder, founded eponymous cosmetics company in 1946 to sell skin cream developed by Hungarian uncle. Now $5.1 billion (sales) company chaired by brother Leonard (see). Onetime deputy assistant secretary of defense under President Reagan, later appointed ambassador to Austria. Active investor in former Communist bloc. Founded and heads Central European Media Enterprises: six television stations in the Slovak Republic, Romania, Ukraine and Slovenia, but lately fighting Czech government over TV contracts. Vast personal art collection valued at $450 million. Looking to revive once-flourishing Hungarian wine industry through Lauder-Láng Vineyards and its Gundel brand wine, maker of chardonnay, merlot, cabernet sauvignon and a series of Tokaji wines. Also stakes in Hungarian paprika and goose liver industries.

name: Billionaires
bio: The largest diamond cutter and polisher in the world. Born in Uzbekistan; his Lubavitcher-Jewish family fled to Israel in 1971. Made his name undercutting the powerful De Beers diamond cartel, striking his own deals with diamond-producing countries like Russia and Angola. Industry insiders speculate he pocketed millions helping oligarchs sell some of Russia’s $12 billion in diamond reserves following the fall of the Iron Curtain. His Lev Leviev Group also includes swimsuitmaker Gottex, 1,700 Fina gas stations in the Southwest U.S. and a stake in Israel’s first toll road. A devout Jew, he donates at least $30 million annually to the Chabad movement, which seeks to return lost Jews to the flock.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built computer from scratch as teenager, got MIT scholarship, worked on college computer magazine. Launched International Data Group in 1964. Today IDG, with flagship Computerworld, publishes more than 300 magazines and newsletters in 85 countries. Also books, trade shows. Sales: $2.4 billion. Rejected going public even in the bubble, though his fortune would have soared.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Honeywell exec became Cisco chief in 1988. Took it public in 1990, stepped down as CEO in 1995. Tech-bust survivor Cisco remains bellwether, posting solid gains in last few quarters. Company expanded beyond core router-and-switch business into Internet telephony and wireless technology.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Henry Samueli (see) founded Broadcom in 1991: manufacturer of high-speed chips for cable modems, set-top boxes. Parted ways in January. Nicholas left to save his marriage, spend more time with his kids; Samueli now sole chairman. Company has returned to profitability as tech economy improves.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers Augusto and Giorgio Perfetti share $2 billion candy fortune. Founded by their father Ambrogio and Uncle Egidio Perfetti in 1946 in a small town near Milan, the company was the first to introduce chewing gum to Italians. Their Brooklyn brand is still one of the most popular in Italy. (The gum was named after American soldiers who chewed gum in Italy during World War II.)   In 2001, Perfetti paid more than $900 million for Van Melle, the Dutch owner of Mentos, Fruittella and Airheads. Since then, company has been run by chief executive Ubaldo Traldi.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sharp-eyed investor and Stanford business grad cut teeth managing Bass family’s $50 million portfolio in 1970, including acquisition of large Disney stake in 1984. Went solo two years later. Cofounded Columbia Hospital 1987, bought Hospital Corporation of America 1994; this year shed HCA in favor of stake in beleaguered Tenet Healthcare. Other investments: oil, real estate through Crescent REIT.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Mitchell, left father’s real estate business in 1979 to strike out on their own. They combined a defunct real estate investment trust with two manufacturing outfits to create Danaher, named for the Montana tributary where the brothers used to catch trout. Acquired and revamped more than three dozen companies in 25 years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fifth wife and widow of Axel Springer, founder of Axel Springer Verlag, publishers of conservative daily Die Welt and tabloid Bild Zeitung, Germany’s largest daily. Last October American investment company Hellman & Friedmann acquired a 19.4% stake, signifying yet another American interloper in the hermetic German media scene after Haim Saban bought ProSiebenSat l. (Friede owns 55%.) A frequent recipient of humanitarian and philanthropic awards, Friede was feted last year by the Jewish Museum in Berlin for her efforts at developing a dialogue between Jews and Gentiles in Germany.

name: Billionaires
bio: U.S. citizen who immigrated to the U.S. from Russia at age 21 with his family and worked his way through college. Founded Access Industries, a Manhattan-based private equity investment firm, in 1986. In 1990 he formed Renova as Access’ Russian affiliate with school friend Viktor Vekselberg (also a billionaire), and they began to acquire stakes in selected, newly privatized Russian companies. To date, Blavatnik’s most successful investment has been the result of a three-way partnership among Access, Renova and the Alfa Group (run by fellow billionaire Mikhail Fridman). The trio, under the umbrella of AAR (Alfa, Access and Renova), owned controlling stakes in the Tyumen Oil Company (TNK), a vertically integrated Russian oil company. In late 2003 AAR and BP jointly formed TNK-BP, Russia’s third-largest oil company, in a deal that netted AAR approximately $6 billion while retaining an approximately 50% interest in TNK-BP. Access and Renova also own a controlling stake in the Siberian-Urals Aluminum Company (SUAL). Other Access investments include coal mines and an integrated electric power company in Kazakhstan as well as other real estate,telecom and entrepreneurial activities worldwide. Active philanthropist.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a Norwegian welder; now controls the world’s largest fleet of oil tankers through publicly traded Frontline Ltd. Almost all of Frontline’s vessels are traded on the spot market, where rates can be unpredictable but also higher when market conditions favor him. Which explains why his 46% stake in Frontline is worth $1 billion this year, up 352% from a year ago.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of three children of Joyce Hall (d.1982), who started selling greeting cards out of Kansas City YMCAs at age 15. Donald took over in 1966; expanded into crayons (Crayola), television production (Hallmark Entertainment), real estate. Hallmark now accounts for more than half of all greeting cards sold in the U.S.

name: Billionaires
bio: Only daughter of late coffee magnate Max Herz. Sided with brother Günter in her siblings’ very public feud for management of the fortune, finally agreeing with him to sell their combined 39.6% of retail group Tchibo Holding to their mother, Ingeburg, and three other brothers for an estimated $5 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Herz siblings have finally ironed out their differences, settling their very public dispute over the management of Tchibo Holding, one of Germany’s largest retail concerns. Last August Günter and sister, Daniela, sold out their combined 39.6% stake to the other three brothers for an estimated $5 billion. Günter is now said to be looking into investment opportunities. In the meantime he continues to raise horses at the stud farm he owns in Schleswig-Holstein.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former car salesman made first high-tech sale in 1982 by hawking his computer with a $3 ad in the Chicago Tribune. Soon after, started Computer Discount Warehouse. Today the company sells $4 billion in computer equipment, software and services. Krasny stepped down as chief executive in 2001.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Steven, left father’s real estate business in 1979 to strike out on their own. They combined a defunct real estate investment trust with two manufacturing outfits to create Danaher, named for the Montana tributary where the brothers used to catch trout. Acquired and revamped more than three dozen companies in 25 years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth-generation banker Schroder continues as a director of his family’s financial services company, Schroders Plc., which celebrates its 200th anniversary this year. With sister, Charmaine, and family trust, has 57.4% stake in Schroders. Revenues down 6% in 2002, but cutting operating costs helped it Schroders swing back to profitability. Stock up 50% in the past 12 months. Schroder still flies planes and spends time at his estate in Islay, Scotland.

name: Billionaires
bio: President of Sibneft, Russia’s fifth-largest oil company. Shvidler trained as an oil engineer in Moscow, received an M.B.A. from New York’s Fordham University, then worked for Deloitte & Touche; became a U.S. citizen. His career took off when he teamed up with Roman Abramovich and established Runicom S.A., a Switzerland-based oil trading firm. In 1995 the men partnered with Boris Berezovsky to gain control of oil giant Sibneft; became president of the company in 1998; together with Abramovich and some other partners, he has pooled his oil, aluminum, timber and industrial assets in a British-based holding company called Millhouse Capital. Last year played a key role in blocking merger of Sibneft with its larger Russian rival Yukos, after top Yukos shareholder Mikhail Khodorkovsky was arrested.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned $2 million investment into $1.3 billion Taylor Corp. printing empire (wedding invitations, stationery, magazines); now retired as CEO, concentrates on philanthropy, agribusiness. Also sports: owns pro basketball’s Timberwolves, WNBA’s Lynx.

name: Billionaires
bio: Back in style. Self-made retailing tycoon returns to the Billionaires list, thanks to a stock that nearly doubled in the past year. His Fast Retailing (known for its Uniqlo brand) is Japan’s answer to the Gap. Operates 635 stores in Japan, Shanghai and London. Plans to expand domestically, opening 51 stores while closing 20 in Japan and two in Shanghai.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of Internet portal Yahoo met partner David Filo (see) in 1989 while pursuing master’s degrees in electrical engineering at Stanford. Became billionaires while working on their Ph.D.s. Taiwanese émigré Yang drew up guide to help navigate World Wide Web in 1994. Landed 112,000 users in five months. Sold minority interest to Sequoia Capital; took public in 1996. Today Yahoo has over 100 million registered users. Partners retain “chief Yahoo” title, but the business is run by former Warner Bros. chief Terry Semel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former World War II infantryman made a mint by helping the populace melt away pounds. Self-professed health enthusiast introduced Slim-Fast nutrition drinks late 1970s; sold to Unilever in 2000 for $2.3 billion. Funds Mayo Clinic, Democrats and his own Center for Middle East Peace and Economic Cooperation, which strives to bring peace to both sides of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

name: Billionaires
bio: Casino mogul doubling down: nearing completion on one of two planned casino resorts in Far East gambling mecca Macau. In Las Vegas, higher casino revenues and room rates at the Venetian, the Strip’s largest hotel. Last year&#39s efforts: opened $45 million addition to his Sands convention center and $250 million tower of suites at the Venetian. Son of Boston cabdriver made first fortune in trade shows, selling Comdex to Japan’s Softbank for $800 million in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low-profile investment banker’s annual retreat for media bigwigs in Sun Valley, Idaho has helped spawn some high-profile mergers like Disney and ABC. Last summer’s confab made all the more enticing with Vivendi Universal on the block. Board member, large investor in Coca-Cola.

name: Billionaires
bio: A fourth-generation banker, Botin chairs Banco Santander Central Hispano, one of Spain’s largest banks. Hit hard by the economic turmoil in Latin America, where it has a large presence, Banco spent last year restructuring and selling off assets. Payoff: a 16.8% rise in net income to $3.2 billion. Daughter Ana Patricia Botin, who is chairman of BSCH’s retail unit Banesto, is likely heir apparent.r.

name: Billionaires
bio: Original partner in Endemol, the TV production outfit behind reality show hits like Big Brother and Fear Factor. In 2000 Spanish telecom giant Telefónica bought Endemol for $5.3 billion. De Mol’s take at the time: $1.4 billion. Will exit Endemol sometime this year after rifts with Telefónica over top management posts. His next step is up for speculation. (Mere rumor: de Mol joins soap opera son on the small screen.) Perhaps there’s an opening at one of the many companies he’s recently funded through his investment arm, Talpa Capital. Among them: Fox Kids Europe, Lycos Europe and Spyker, a new Dutch car maker.

name: Billionaires
bio: After a couple of bumpy years, chairman of fifth-largest cable operator focusing on core business: jettisoned consumer electronics retailer the Wiz, 80% stake in cable channel Bravo. Stock up 50% in past year. Son, James, CEO since 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: With his father opened a discount supermarket in the late 1970s. Ultimately partnered with supermarket giant Ahold, pocketing a cash payout and 20% stake. When the deal gets renegotiated late this year, expect each to make a play for the other one’s holding. Also has significant stakes in Orkla, a large Norwegian outfit with interests in chemicals, consumer goods and financial services; also Steen & Strom, which owns shopping centers. One of his daughters sits on the board of his investment firm, Canica. Reportedly owns one of the biggest sailboats in Europe and his own island in the Caribbean.

name: Billionaires
bio: Billion-dollar beneficiary of Citigroup’s 2001 buyout of Banamex, Harp now spends much of his time tending to his nation’s poor. Through the Banamex Social Foundation he oversees development aid to the impoverished of south Mexican state of Oaxaca. Also a big baseball fan, he owns a Mexican team, and titled his recent autobiography "To Live and Die Playing Baseball."

name: Billionaires
bio: College dropout launched garbage collection company with used truck 1962. Became Waste Management. Scrapped trash business 1984, bought 19-store video rental chain Blockbuster 1987; sold to Viacom seven years later for $8.4 billion. Reinvested in car lots (AutoNation), lodging (Boca Resorts, Extended Stay America). Sold Florida Marlins baseball franchise after winning 1997 World Series. Still owns pro football’s Miami Dolphins.

name: Billionaires
bio: Three decades after planting his first 20 acres of grapes, onetime attorney has built Kendall-Jackson into one of America's most valuable wineries by offering blended chardonnays and other varietals appealing to affluent masses. Now devoting efforts to independent boutique wineries like Lokoya and Hartford Court, owned with wife Barbara Banke and family, and to international winery efforts in Chile, Italy and Australia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Korean chipmaker started Amkor Technology as U.S. marketing arm of father’s Anam Industrial, provides semiconductor packaging, testing. IPO 1998. Sales now $1.6 billion, but stock lately a roller coaster: Amkor down 70% 2002, up 230% in 2003. Now trying to penetrate Chinese semiconductor market. Also owns stake in Electronics Boutique, mall kiosk operator started by wife, Agnes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of Harvard Ph.D. program after bout of writer’s block; took job as New York cab driver. Started trading commodities age 31 with $3,000 loan, racked up consistent annual gains. Started Caxton hedge fund 1983, now manages $11 billion in assets; signature fund up 26.5% in 2002 on big wins in bonds, currency markets. Chairman of conservative American Enterprise Institute spent $2 million publishing a fully illustrated version of the King James Bible.

name: Billionaires
bio: A well-known philanthropist, he has given away millions through his Lee Foundation for schools, scholarships and educational programs. Recently donated $36 million for a new National Library in Singapore. Fortune comes from Overseas-Chinese Banking Corp., one of the largest in Singapore. Stepped down as chairman in March 2003 but retains a position on the board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Right-hand man of TCI founder Bob Magness (d. 1996); became CEO, sold TCI to AT&T in 1999. When AT&T sold the cable systems to Comcast in 2002, Malone got stock. Through investment vehicle Liberty Media owns big stakes in Time Warner, Barry Diller's InterActiveCorp and UnitedGlobalCom. Also News Corp.: recently raised eyebrows by quietly increasing his already sizable stake.

name: Billionaires
bio: After a yearlong, six-way bidding war Sir Kenneth emerged the winner of Safeway supermarkets in December, when his more than $5 billion stock-and-cash offer was accepted. The deal, approved in February, ups his Wm Morrison Supermarket’s share of the grocery market to 16%, tying for third-largest grocery in the U.K.

name: Billionaires
bio: It was a year of recovery for infotech billionaire Nadar’s $1 billion (revenues) HCL group. Flagship HCL Technologies’ stock soared 85%. The firm also won new clients like Airbus and a $160 million business process outsourcing contract from British Telecom. Sold his 50% stake in software firm HCL-Perot to Perot for $105 million; now he’s shopping for acquisitions. Established the Shiv Nadar Institute of Technology in southern Indian city of Chennai. Collects contemporary Indian art and is a big cricket fan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Subject of scandal in January when it was revealed he and a partner surreptitiously bought the discounted debt of one of his companies&#39 subsidiaries and then sold it back to the company, TV Azteca, at face value, pocketing close to $200 million in the process. No surprise, he&#39s now the target of a raft of class-actions filed in New York by shareholders of TV Azteca, Mexico&#39s second-largest broadcaster. Salinas also owns most of the Mexican retailer and consumer bank Grupo Elektra. In happier news, Salinas&#39 wife, María Laura Medina Espinosa, bore him a son in October. Young Ricardo is the couple&#39s first child.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Peter Nicholas (see) founded Broadcom in 1991: manufacturer of high-speed chips for cable modems, set-top boxes. Parted ways in January. Samueli now sole chairman after Nicholas left. Company has returned to profitability as tech economy improves.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Humanities professor with Ph.D. from Cambridge. After bosses at San Jose State University turned down his proposal for adult-education program, started Apollo Group’s for-profit University of Phoenix; took public in 1994. Today the nation’s largest private university system: more than 150,000 students on 67 campuses and in 118 learning centers. Iconoclast supports cloning research, marijuana legalization. Son Peter (see) serves as Apollo’s 
senior vice president.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of John Sperling (see), a humanities professor with Ph.D. from Cambridge. After bosses at San Jose State University turned down his proposal for adult-education program, elder Sperling started Apollo Group’s for-profit University of Phoenix; took public in 1994. Today the nation’s largest private university system: more than 150,000 students on 67 campuses and in 118 learning centers. Son Peter serves as Apollo’s senior vice president.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of Homer Stryker (d. 1980), orthopedic surgeon who invented mobile hospital bed. After father Lee died in 1977 plane crash, John Brown (see) became head of Stryker Corp. With sisters Pat and Ronda (see both) controls 30% of company. Architect Jon splits time between Michigan and Palm Beach, Fla.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of Homer Stryker (d. 1980), orthopedic surgeon who invented mobile hospital bed. After father Lee died in 1977 plane crash, John Brown (see) became head of Stryker Corp. With siblings Pat and Jon (see both) controls 30% of company. Ronda sits on board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Expanded fortune saving conglomerate Morrison Knudsen 1996; later renamed Washington Group, filed Chapter 11. Owns Canada’s largest tug-and-barge company, fleet of trans-Pacific container ships. Owns island with golf course in British Columbia. Other passion: overhauling wrecked 204-foot yacht.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of Royal Caribbean, the $3.8 billion (sales) leisure-cruise behemoth. Last year stepped down from the company’s board after 35 years of service, during which time he never missed a board meeting. Replaced by son, Alex. The elder Wilhelmsen  is also principal of Oslo-based shipping and investment company, Anders Wilhelmsen & Co AS, which boasts investments in oil tankers, real estate and international equities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Esprit’s American founders Douglas and Susie Tompkins gave Ying his big break when they hired him as Esprit’s primary sourcing agent in 1971; later he set up the company’s Asian distributorship, Esprit Far East, which listed on the Hong Kong stock exchange in 1993. Esprit de Corp, the U.S. company, was taken over by creditors in 1996, but in Asia the brand had thrived under Ying; In 1996 he acquired Esprit’s European operations, renaming the company Esprit Holdings; In 2002 he paid $150 million for the rights to the brand in the U.S. Last year Ying stepped aside but remains chairman, naming former Esprit Europe head Heinz Krogner chief executive. So far so good—company posted record profits for the fiscal year ending June 2003.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bogdanov studied oil engineering in university, started out as an assistant driller. In 1984, at age 33, was named general director of Surgutneftegaz—now Russia’s fourth-largest oil company. During the privatization auctions of 1994 and 1995 grabbed control for himself and fellow managers. Is known in Russia as a competent, hard-working and honest industrial tycoon; many regard Surgutneftegaz as the best-managed oil company in Russia, though outside investors grumble at the company’s paltry dividends, primitive accounting and underutilized cash hoard. Exceptionally private: dubbed the “Hermit of Siberia,” Bogdanov rarely leaves his remote oil town, avoids the press and shuns the trappings of wealth; until recently, he used to walk to work and did his own grocery shopping.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest of four brothers, Dhanin was just 25 when took over the family’s small seed shop. Transformed it into one of the world’s largest suppliers of animal feed. Fluent in Thai and Mandarin, Dhanin began investing in Mainland China as early as 1979. Today he can count more than 100 feed mills in 29 of China’s 31 provinces; his chain of discount retailers, under the name Lotus Supercenters, has more than 14 outlets in China. Today his Thailand-based CP Group also has operations and investments in telecommunications, marketing, distribution and real estate development. Spends his free time breeding native Thai chickens. Recent avian influenza outbreak is hurting his poultry business, but luckily he has other interests to bolster his fortune.

name: Billionaires
bio: Medical doctor founded Hospital Corp. of America with father in 1968 following stint as Air Force flight surgeon. Merged with Columbia Healthcare in 1994. Now nation’s largest for-profit hospital operator. Came out of retirement to help nurse company through lengthy Medicare-fraud investigation. Second retirement should go more smoothly: HCA settled with the Department of Justice last July for $631 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of German software giant SAP. A mathematician by training, Hector successfully built up SAP’s North American market, but fell out with his partners in 1997. Now focuses on managing H.W.& J. Hector Stiftung, his cultural and philanthropic foundation, which supports cancer and AIDS research, as well as art and historical preservation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns 28.7% of construction giant Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas, founded by her father in 1944. The outfit builds most of Spain’s bridges and highways. A healthy domestic market has offset slower international growth.  The $7 billion (2002 sales) company expects to report a 4% rise in profits for 2003. In June the eligible divorcee married Fernando Falco, Marques de Cubas, an old friend and scion of an old Spanish family.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of John T. Dorrance, founder of Campbell Soup, inventor of condensed-soup process. Left half his fortune to son, John Jr. (d. 1989), the rest to his three daughters. Mary Alice breeds horses on 400-acre farm in Pennsylvania.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ex-Campbell Soup accountant joined premium pet-food maker Paul Iams in 1970; bought out partner in 1982. Targeted high-end breeders, veterinarians. Sold Iams to Procter & Gamble for $2.3 billion in 1999. Mathile Family Foundation supports Ohio causes, entrepreneurs in developing nations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ninth-grade dropout made first fortune in post-WWII housing boom, lost it all in 1964 real estate crash. Started again with California properties. In 1985 took-over nearly bankrupted Hawaii-based Castle & Cooke, which owned pineapple producer Dole and had a large real estate portfolio. Has profited handsomely from that transaction: developed real estate into residential and commercial properties; Dole Foods, the world&#39s largest producer of fruits and vegetables, generates more than $135 million in free cash flow a year. Keeps 400 Arabian horses on his 2,000-acre estate in California where he also displays the 300 boulders he mined from Thailand’s River Kwai. Spending millions to promote healthy eating.

name: Billionaires
bio: Longtime head of Richemont, the Swiss-based luxury-products group whose brands include Cartier and Dunhill. Richemont&#39s performance has been lackluster due to luxury-goods slump but things are picking up. (Sales for the quarter ending Dec. 2003 were down 4% but December sales were up 10%). Rupert has assumed an active role in trying to turn things around. Recently bought out a group of family and friends who had been longtime Richemont shareholders, increasing his family’s stake to 9.1% of equity. He spearheaded an acquisition of the remaining 20% of Van Cleef & Arpels Richemont hadn’t owned. Rupert is also nonexecutive chairman of Remgro and Venfin, two South African holding companies. Off hours: Rupert is an avid golfer. The family also owns L’Ormarins and La Motte, two South African vineyards.

name: Billionaires
bio: Self-described “cartoon schlepper” introduced Mighty Morphin Power Rangers in the U.S. in 1993. With Rupert Murdoch’s Fox TV, formed Fox Family network; sold to Disney in 2001. His take: $1.5 billion. Reinvesting some of the proceeds into ProSiebenSat.1, the big German broadcaster owned by bankrupt KirchMedia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and chief executive of Quebec-based Saputo Inc., Canada’s largest dairy processor. Sales topped $3.4 billion in year ending March 2003. Company markets dairy products under several brands, including Dairyland, Dragone, Stella. In November acquired Molfino Hermanos S.A., Argentina’s third-largest dairy processor, for $51 million. Son of a cheesemaker, Saputo helped his Italian family start a mom-and-pop dairy company shortly after moving to Canada in 1952. Became big cheese himself in 1969 when named chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: When Wen-Long Shi wants to schmooze bankers, he gives a spirited violin concert. A talented violinist, he has proven even more successful in business. The leader of Chi-Mei Corp., Shi built his fortune in the plastics business in southern Taiwan. But he returns to the billionaires? list this year thanks to his successful diversification into flat-panel manufacturing. His Chi Mei Optoelectronics is now one of the world's biggest makers of large-sized LCD TV screens. A dedicated fisherman and arts enthusiast, Shi helps finance a  museum near his hometown of Tainan, Taiwan, whose eclectic collection includes among other things ancient Egyptian objects, German flintlock pistols and?no surprise?violins. ?

name: Billionaires
bio: Made his fortune from retailer Mango, which sells trendy women’s apparel at affordable prices. Opened his first store in Barcelona in 1984. Now has more than 700 locations in 72 countries; 2003 sales expected to exceed $1.2 billion. Little is known about secretive Andic, whose family came to Spain from Turkey in the 1960s. Apparently loves to sail

name: Billionaires
bio: Former money man for George Soros famous for orchestrating his boss’ billion-dollar raid on the British pound in 1992 with timely short position. Helped generate string of 30% returns for Soros’ Quantum Fund. Parted from Soros in 2000 after sustaining massive tech sector losses. Now runs Pittsburgh-based Duquesne Capital and No Margin Fund. Former chairman of Paul Tudor Jones’ Robin Hood Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Three-time loser in New York State gubernatorial quest despite spending $74 million on most recent campaign. May get a few more votes after $92 million bailout of bankrupt Buffalo Sabres kept hockey team in town. Started payroll-processing business with one employee in 1971. Paychex IPO in 1983 made millionaires of original 18 partners. Now $1.1 billion in sales with plenty of room to grow; company says fewer than 20% of small businesses outsource payroll. Paychex spending like its founder: cash acquisitions of Advantage Payroll Services for $240 million September 2002, $182 million for Interpay in April 2003.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alec, with brother Tom, emigrated from Israel, worked together in buyouts until 1995. Alec runs Gores Technology Group: conglomerate of 40 companies, including 2000 acquisition (and quick turnaround) of Learning Company from Mattel. Known for buying up pieces of troubled technology businesses. December 2003: bought unprofitable U.S.-based Web hosting and networking firm owned by Britain's Cable & Wireless for $125 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tom, with brother Alec (see), emigrated from Israel, worked together in buyouts until 1995. Alec runs Gores Technology Group: conglomerate of 40 companies, including 2000 acquisition (and quick turnaround) of Learning Company from Mattel. Tom heads up Platinum Equity: 20 companies, $4 billion in sales. This year bought historic MCA building in Beverly Hills, former Global Crossing HQ.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Enron president left firm 1996, uncomfortable with “asset-light” strategy. Bought Enron’s asset rich liquid-gas pipeline operations with college classmate William Morgan. Today Kinder Morgan controls over 35,000 miles of pipe, transports 2 million barrels of fuel products and 14 billion cubic feet of natural gas a day. Vietnam vet avoids Enron excesses: flies coach class, pays himself just $1 a year. Wife, Nancy, is south Texas finance chairman for the Bush-Cheney 2004 reelection campaign.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Alfred Lerner (d. 2002), furniture salesman who invested earnings in Cleveland-area real estate. After father&#39s death, brother Randy Lerner (see) got pro football’s Browns franchise, which father brought back to Cleveland in 1999; daughter Nancy inherited stake in Maryland REIT Town and Country Trust.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Alfred Lerner, furniture salesman who invested earnings in Cleveland-area real estate, banking. Bought control of Equitable Bancorp 1981, merged with Maryland National 1989; spun off MBNA 1991. After his death in 2002, son Randy inherited pro football’s Browns franchise, which father brought back to Cleveland in 1999; daughter Nancy got stake in Maryland REIT Town and Country Trust.

name: Billionaires
bio: High school dropout turned reclusive billionaire. Born in London’s East End, he helped expand the family’s catering business as a teen. Gradually moved into currency trading in the late 1970s. He’s the primary investor in Tavistock Group, which has interests in more than 100 companies including several San Diego biotech outfits, a Russian oil & gas concern and Mexico’s distributor of Puma and Gottex. Also owns two exclusive golf communities in Orlando, Fla.:—Isleworth Country Club, whose residents include Tiger Woods and Shaquille O’Neal, and Lake Nona Golf & Country Club, home to golfers Ernie Els, Annika Sorenstam and Sergio Garcia. In March staging first annual Tavistock Cup, a team competition (with $1.4 million purse) between top golfers living in the two communities. Currently resides in Lyford Cay, Bahamas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took over father’s insurance company in 1965; grew Progressive Corp. into the third-largest U.S. auto insurer by targeting high-risk drivers. Active philanthropist embroiled in love-hate relationship with Case Western Reserve University: gave $36.9 million to build Frank Gehry-designed business school, then froze donations to Cleveland nonprofits to protest university’s financial and academic decline: “I’ve always liked shaking things up.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of high school age 14 to help run family’s dairy business. Started ice cream store with brothers 1940, became United Dairy Farmers. Diversified into banks, insurance, bananas. With three sons, controls roughly 42% of American Financial Group. A principal owner and chief executive of baseball’s Cincinnati Reds.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ex-wife of Amancio Ortega, Spain’s richest man. In the early days helped then-husband get Inditex textile company off the ground. Today she has a 7% stake in the $5 billion (sales) company and sits on the board. Has also invested in Spanish companies like Zeltia, a chemical company looking for cancer treatments in compounds found in the sea, and ICN, which makes a specialized fingerprinting identification system for newborn babies
title: Investor, Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: Wildcatter struck gold in north Texas gas fields. Started Mitchell Energy & Development in 1946, sold to Devon Energy in 2001 for $3.5 billion. Longtime environmentalist now looking to save the planet; opposed oil drilling in Alaska wildlife refuge, funded a $10 million National Academies study on sustainable development and population growth.

name: Billionaires
bio: President of $1 billion (sales) Aruze, the largest Japanese slot machine maker. Company has been hit with a number of lawsuits related to charges of tax evasion and violation of antimonopoly law. Okada is partnering with American Steve Wynn to develop a $2.4 billion casino resort in Las Vegas slated for a 2005 opening. Younger brother committed suicide last year in Las Vegas by injecting ricin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold shares in Argentina’s largest energy company in 2002. Now concentrates on his  $684 million (revenues) Molinos de la Plata, one of Argentina&#39s biggest processed-food companies, ably assisted by sons Jorge and Luis. Perez Companc collects vintage cars, while wife Maria Carmen raises Jersey cows and uses their milk to make ice cream, sold through her Munchi’s ice cream chain.

name: Billionaires
bio: After a failed 1997 attempt to become Hong Kong’s first chief executive, headed the Hong Kong Trade Development Council for four years. In 2002 returned to the helm of Wheelock & Co., the company founded by his father-in-law, the late Sir Y.K. Pao.  Rumors are swirling that Woo is considering a reverse takeover by Wharf Holdings, a sister company in which Wheelock has a majority stake. Returns to the list this year thanks to Wheelock’s rising stock.

name: Billionaires
bio: Beverage whiz from Thailand, well known there for producing and selling drinks with names like Krating Daeng. Teamed up with Austrian Dietrich Mateschitz and began marketing Red Bull energy drink worldwide. Also has a stake in a private hospital in Thailand that caters mostly to foreign patients

name: Billionaires
bio: Market upturn easing stress on Bass family fortune after liquidity crunch, bad tech bets forced Sid Bass to sell large chunk of Disney stake to meet margin call. Father Perry built on oil fortune inherited from uncle Sid Richardson (d. 1951). Handed business to eldest son, Sid, in 1968, prompting Robert (see) to break out on his own. Investments include Hawthorne Financial, Iomega, oil and gas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold Banco Bozano, Simonsen, which he cofounded, to Spain’s Banco Santander Central Hispano in early 2000. Now he no longer makes business headlines. Reportedly lives in Greenwich, Conn. and has a pied-a-terre in Rio. Bozano’s 12.6% stake in jetmaker Embraer rocketed up nearly 80% in the last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of John T. Dorrance, founder of Campbell Soup, inventor of condensed-soup process. Heads DMB & Associates, real estate developer in Arizona.

name: Billionaires
bio: Farm boy turned thrift-trader bought first bank in 1975 for $1.2 million, later sold for $80 million profit. Biggest score: selling California’s Golden State Bancorp to Citigroup for $6 billion in 2002; personal stake now worth more than $1.1 billion. Other investments include auto-finance company AmeriCredit, 120,000 acres of ranch land in New Mexico.

name: Billionaires
bio:
DARYL KATZ, CANADA, 42
The son of a pharmacist cobbled together 1,700 pharmacies to create the seventh-largest pharmacy chain in the Western Hemisphere in just under a decade. The Edmonton-based Katz Group—pronounced Cates—is one of Canada’s largest private companies. His formula: Buy up distressed pharmacy chains with the help of drug distributor McKesson, then hire capable execs to turn the chains around. Suffered his first major setback last year when his U.S. arm filed for bankruptcy. The setback was largely offset by gains made by his Canadian stores, which benefited from a soaring Canadian dollar. Katz is looking to link his Canadian stores under a common banner, Rexall. The branding scheme includes plans to construct the Rexall National Tennis Centre in Toronto and rename the home of hockey’s Edmonton Oilers as Rexall Place. Though he eschews the limelight, Katz is known as a tough dealmaker who bulldozes those who get in his way.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather founded Kohler Co. in 1873 to make hitching posts and cemetery ornaments for Midwest farmers. Kohler today is a leading manufacturer of kitchen and bath fixtures, furniture, generators. Sales: $3 billion. Yale graduate is an avid breeder of Morgan show horses: “A terrific animal. So beautiful and showy.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Hard-nosed chairman of ESL Investments had a rough 2002: $5 billion fund reportedly down 15% after returning 66% in 2001. Spent several hundred million dollars buying distressed Kmart bonds; now holds controlling interest after hauling the company out of bankruptcy in May 2003. Risk taker also has large stakes in Sears, AutoZone. Got start with summer job at Goldman Sachs; launched ESL Investments 1998. High-profile client roster includes Michael Dell, David Geffen.

name: Billionaires
bio: Power struggle for McCain Foods has led to strained relations with billionaire brother Harrison. Family feud forced Wallace out in 1993. Took over meat processor Maple Leaf Foods in 1995. Tough 2003: Maple Leaf profits down more than 85% in the first nine months. Wallace’s daughter is aspiring singer Eleanor McCain, who waxed on about the brothers’ long-standing feud in her 2001 debut album.

name: Billionaires
bio: Granddaughter of company founder Mario Prada runs $1.7 billion (2002 sales) luxury-goods maker with husband, Patrizio Bertelli. She is lead designer; he is chief executive. Last year signed a ten-year licensing agreement with Italian eyeglass manufacturer Luxottica and opened 10 new stores, including a flagship location in Tokyo. The group, which has 260 stores around the globe, has been slashing debt by spinning off real estate and selling a stake in British shoemaker Church’s. Prada hopes to finally go public later this year or early next year, several years after first announcing plans for an offering. Husband is an avid sailor who has competed in the America’s Cup. For the past decade the couple has been hosting shows of internationally recognized contemporary artists through their foundation.
title: Owner, Fashion Designer

name: Billionaires
bio: Schoolteacher’s son and onetime bank examiner with a taste for takeovers. Bought Dallas drugstore for $5,000 in 1961; sold chain to Eckerd for $50 million 12 years later. Built holding company Valhi through hostile takeovers; now owns major pieces of chemical, metal and waste-management businesses.

name: Billionaires
bio: With siblings Ronda and Jon (see) controls Stryker Corp., medical supply company founded by grandfather Homer (d. 1980). First hospital beds; later specialty stretchers, cast cutters. Low-profile heiress becoming more active in civic life: donated $3 million to defeat 2002 ballot initiative that would have gutted bilingual education in Colorado. Last year gave $20 million to Colorado State University, mostly to benefit football team. Bought Sonoma’s Sommer Vineyards in 1999, rebuilt, replanted, changed name to Stryker Sonoma: 32 acres in Alexander Valley, producer of classic vinifera varietals Gewürztraminer and Zinfandel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made it big on cigarettes and liquor in the Philippines. His Fortune Tobacco, which supplies some 67% of all smokers in the country, faces a crackdown. The government is considering raising taxes on tobacco companies and passing antismoking legislation. Forays into banking and aviation have proved to be far less profitable. Rumor has it that Philippines Airlines is again up for sale.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned an obscure Kyoto playing-card company into one of the world’s best-known game companies, Nintendo. Stepped down as chief executive in May 2002 after 53 years; remains an adviser. Has also been funding a group of game developers, using his personal money; obviously in search of a new smash-hit game for Nintendo machines. Meanwhile, Nintendo continues to battle against fierce competitors Sony’s PlayStation and Microsoft’s Xbox.

name: Billionaires
bio: A former plastics engineer, his career took off when his brother-in-law Yuri Luzhkov became mayor of Moscow in 1992. Transformed his municipal Committee for Science & Technology into a commercial enterprise, gained access to lucrative government contracts, real estate and capital. His empire, AFK Sistema (“The System”), now consists of some 200 companies with holdings ranging from microchips to toy stores. Most valuable is 50% stake in MTS, Russia’s largest cellular company. Denies that his company was started with municipal government financial aid; insists he accumulated his first capital exporting oil, importing electronics and food products in early 1990s. According to Forbes’ sources, owns 25% of AFK Sistema.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Ethiopian-born and raised in Saudi Arabia, Al Amoudi made his fortune in construction and real estate before branching out to buy oil refineries in Sweden and Morocco. He is said to be the largest foreign investor in both Sweden and his native Ethiopia, where some of his ventures include mines and hotels. One is the Addis Ababa Sheraton Hotel, the most lavish hotel in the country where former Treasury Secretary O&#39Neill and Bono stayed while on their African tour a couple of years ago.

From 2004 bio:
Mohammed Hussein Al Amoudi
Born in Ethiopia and raised in Saudi Arabia, Al Amoudi made his fortune in construction and real estate before expanding into oil refineries in Sweden and Morocco. Said to be the largest foreign investor in both Sweden and his native Ethiopia. One notable Ethiopian property: his lavish Sheraton Addis Ababa Hotel, which played host to former Treasury Secretary Paul O’Neill and U2 front man Bono while they toured Africa a couple of years ago.

name: Billionaires
bio: While running a car repair business 15 years ago, found he could get a discount on cell phones if he became a dealer and bought in bulk. Took him eight months to sell his first 26 phones from a Stoke-on-Trent, England store. The following year he sold approximately $1.5 million worth and the business doubled in size every year until 1995. Projected 2003 sales: $4 billion. Meanwhile, his seven-year-old Caudwell Charitable Trust has raised $3 billion to provide treatment or grant dying wishes for children.

name: Billionaires
bio: A secretive and committed Buddhist, Chen delisted his flagship company Nan Fung Textiles back in 1989. Riding the real estate boom of the 1990s, Chen seemed to have fared well despite the economic downturn. He bought some 12% of fellow billionaire Ng Teng Fong’s Sinoland and built up its portfolio of luxury properties.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded in 1969 with a single drugstore, the Jean Coutu Group now includes more than 650 stores in the U.S. and Canada. In the U.S. the stores operate as Brooks Pharmacy and are concentrated in New England. Coutu made news recently by teaming up with investment firms Thomas H. Lee and Blackstone Group to make a play for J.C. Penney’s Eckerd drugstore chain. But his partners reportedly bailed out, leaving Coutu with a weaker hand. Outcome should be known shortly. Coutu relinquished the chief executive title to son François in September 2002, but remains chairman. Son Michel is chief executive of the U.S. business.

name: Billionaires
bio: With son, Heinrich Otto, and wife, Ruth, steers Deichmann-Schuhe GmbH, one of Europe&#39s largest shoe retailers. Deichmann gave up his orthopedic practice in 1956 to take over the now $26.4 billion (revenues) business his father founded in 1913. Last year the company sold some 90 million pairs of shoes. A household name in Germany, Deichmann shoes are known for being inexpensive yet sturdy. In the U.S. the shoes are sold in chains like Rack Room Shoes and Off Broadway. A committed philanthropist, he supports various missionary and humanitarian organizations and has received numerous decorations from the German government as a result. Like fellow billionaire Hubert Burda, he’s a member of the European Council of Israel’s Ben-Gurion University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime entertainment mogul says the real future lies online. His InterActiveCorp owns Expedia, Hotels.com, Match.com, Ticketmaster, Home Shopping Network.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder, father figure of PeopleSoft watching as his brainchild eludes the grasp of rival Larry Ellison&#39s hostile takeover bid. Cornell M.B.A. took firm public in 1992. Now chairman. Stepped back from day-to-day in 1999. Became 2nd-largest enterprise-software maker in U.S. with $1.8 billion purchase of J.D. Edwards in July. Started $240 million Maddie’s Fund (named for his late schnauzer) to make America a “no-kill” zone for unwanted pets.

name: Billionaires
bio: With sister Marilyn Nelson (see), inherited travel-hospitality conglomerate Carlson Cos. from father, Curtis Carlson: Radisson and Regent Hotels, eatery T.G.I. Friday’s, Seven Seas cruise line. Marilyn CEO since 1998. Barbara heads family foundation, active with children’s charities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Computer engineering professor at UC, San Diego patented code division multiple access technology, pushed to make it the standard for wireless devices. Qualcomm survived the telecom bust, now finding new customers—and profits—in increasingly wireless world. Pledged $120 million to San Diego Symphony.

name: Billionaires
bio: In the 1980s Khan studied at the Moscow Institute of Steel & Alloys, where he met several members of what would later become the Alfa Group, headed by Mikhail Fridman. Khan became the point man for the group’s most lucrative business line—in 1990, coordinating wholesale operations for trading house Alfa Echo and in 1992 supervising exports. By 1994 Khan had helped make Alfa Echo one of Russia’s largest private oil traders and helped set up a big oil-for-sugar deal with Cuba. When Alfa took over oil giant TNK, it was Khan who was chosen to run the operation. Today TNK is half-owned by BP, but Khan retains his hold on the tiller, serving as executive director.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded by his father in 1926, Rahmi ran the Koc Group from 1984 until 2003. In May, passed along the chief executive title to son Mustafa. Koc&#39s three largest subsidiaries—autos, manufacturing and home appliances—are the biggest contributors to the group’s earnings; expects to report a 600% increase in profits for 2003.
