A fit 72-year-old and an avid sailor, Koc reportedly plans to fill his retirement schedule with projects such as funding archaeological digs at the ancient city of Aphrodisias.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of Spain’s wealthiest women. In the 1960s she and older sister Esther inherited construction giant Fomentos de Construcciones y Contratas, the company their father founded in 1944. In 1997 sold her shares to Esther for $800 million. Since then has been carefully investing in real estate, hotels and companies such as Nestle and Telefonica. The Spanish beauty, who recently turned 51 and is divorced, is considered one of Spain’s most eligible women. Has a charitable foundation that helps children and adolescents

name: Billionaires
bio: Stan made his fortune in real estate, including shopping centers anchored by Wal-Mart stores. Big landowner: recently purchased 500,000-acre spread in British Columbia formerly owned by WorldCom’s Bernie Ebbers. Also owns pro basketball’s Denver Nuggets, hockey’s Colorado Avalanche and a stake in football’s St. Louis Rams.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs publicly traded L.E. Lundbergforetagen AB, in which he has a 67% stake. Founded by his father in 1944 as a construction outfit; has evolved into a property management and investment group. Real estate accounts for an estimated 70% of sales. Enjoys hunting and curling (he was a one-time junior world champion); sits on board of Stockholm School of Economics, along with fellow Swedish billionaire Stefan Persson.

name: Billionaires
bio: A marketing executive turned entrepreneur.  In 1984 teamed up with Thai businessman Chaleo Yoovidhya, who manufactured high-energy beverages, to sell the concoctions to European consumers. Renamed the drink Red Bull, packaged it in sleek silver-and-blue cans and marketed it to young people using cheeky advertising. Not everyone approves of the drink: France wants to ban it, claiming its high caffeine content makes it unhealthy. Last year Mateschitz announced plans to step back from the day-to-day business to focus on pet projects like Hangar-7, an event center located on the grounds of Salzburg Airport that opened last summer to much fanfare. The hangar houses his historic aircraft collection, the Flying Bulls, an art gallery and a restaurant. Still owns 49% of the $1.3 billion (sales) company. Owns the island resort of Laucala in Fiji, which he acquired from the Forbes family last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: With sister Barbara Gage (see) inherited travel-hospitality conglomerate Carlson Cos. from father, Curtis Carlson: Radisson and Regent Hotels, eatery T.G.I. Friday’s, Seven Seas cruise line. Marilyn CEO since 1998. Barbara heads family foundation, active with children’s charities.

name: Billionaires
bio: With James Goodnight, co-owner of SAS Institute, world’s largest privately held software company. Company once again tinkering with the idea of going public, promoting “brand awareness” at West Coast investment banking conferences. Good timing as Silicon Valley rivals Oracle and PeopleSoft are engaged in brutal takeover battle. Techie employees kept happy with precrash perks like Olympic-size swimming pool, 35-hour workweek, free soda.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of Colombia’s richest men. Through his majority stake of Grupo Empresarial Bavaria and holding company Grupo Empresarial Valores Bavaria he controls more than 100 companies in a variety of industries. Interests include breweries, newspapers, crude oil production and temporary staffing. Educated at Phillips Academy Andover and the University of Virginia, Santo Domingo is a familiar figure in the international jet set. Now 80, seems to be spending more time at home on his luxurious private island of Baru, near the Colombian colonial city of Cartagena de las Indias..

name: Billionaires
bio: Despite almost 40 years of guerrilla warfare and the entrenched traffic in narcotics, it’s business as usual for one of Colombia’s richest men. His massive banking conglomerate Aval owns such profitable Colombian banks as Banco de Bogota and Banco Occident. Last May joined fellow Latin American billionaires Andronico Luksic of Chile and Gustavo Cisneros of Venezuela at a conference called by Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim to discuss the region’s economic and social problems

name: Billionaires
bio: Yale economics undergrad wrote thesis on improving delivery services via integrated network of planes and trucks. Started with small stake in Arkansas aviation firm; turned into courier service Federal Express. Today 643 planes and 70,000 trucks deliver more than 5 million packages a day. December: company announced plans to buy privately held Kinkos for $2.4 billion in cash.

name: Billionaires
bio: South African native moved to Los Angeles 1980, took faculty position at UCLA’s medical school; left to commercialize research in bioengineered nanoparticles and drug delivery. Now owns stake in American Pharmaceutical Partners, manufacturer of generic injectable drugs. Awaiting FDA approval to market his first proprietary cancer drug, Abraxane.

name: Billionaires
bio: Last month the Stroher family sold their almost 80% stake in Wella AG, the world’s second biggest professional hair care group, to Proctor & Gamble for $4 billion. This after months of hotly denying rumors. Silvia Ströher’s 25% share has made this great-granddaughter of the company founder a very wealthy woman. She’s married to Ulrich Ströher, né Fette, a former male nurse who took her name when they married.

name: Billionaires
bio: Asia’s King of Malls heads publicly traded SM Prime, which operates 15 “supermalls” in the Philippines. Sy also operates the cinemas in his malls. With a total seating capacity of 90,000, Sy is also the largest cinema operator in the Philippines.

name: Billionaires
bio: College dropout flew for Pan Am for ten years. Launched pilot-training school FlightSafety International in 1951. Took public 1968. Sold to Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway in 1996. Chairman of Orbis International, nonprofit group operating airplanes outfitted as modern ophthalmological labs for doctors in developing countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime loan processor, former partner of John Sobrato (see). Tech bankruptcies have bumped up vacancies at the properties owned by his Mission West Properties REIT to 20%, but he claims he’s doing better than the Silicon Valley average. Divides his time among assorted tech investments such as consulting firm International Network Services, which he bought from Lucent Technologies in 2002.

name: Billionaires
bio: Missed the Billionaires’ list for the past two years but now returns thanks to a strong Italian stock market. With family, owns 50% in Caltagirone SpA, the industrial holding company. The company has cement, media and real estate interests. Unsuccessfully bid for Metrovacesa, a Spanish property holding company. Board member of Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena.

name: Billionaires
bio: Internet innovator ran Web radio firm Broadcast.com through frothy years of Internet bubble, sold to Yahoo for $5.7 billion in 1999. His bubble never burst: secured fortune with zero-cost collars. Spent $307 million on pro basketball’s Dallas Mavericks and majority stake in team’s arena. Spent a little more mouthing off to game officials: fined record $1.5 million by NBA his first two years owning team. Turned one of league’s worst-run franchises into recent powerhouse. With former Web partner Todd Wagner (see) dabbles in Hollywood films, HDTV broadcasting via HDNet.

name: Billionaires
bio: Aided by the strengthening of the Brazilian real and a 62% rebound in the stock of retailer Companhia Brasileira de Distribuicao, Diniz rejoins the billionaire ranks. Though he stepped down as chief executive of CBD in December 2002, Diniz remains active as chairman, still going to the office every day. A squash player and marathon runner, Diniz works out every day for three hours

name: Billionaires
bio: Vice chairman and largest single shareholder (12.1%) in security firm Securitas AB, Douglas has benefited from the company&#39s growing dominance of the global security market, a 7% share in 2002 and growing. Count Douglas also holds shares in Assa Abloy, the world’s largest lock producer;  Attendo Senior Care, a private company that provides alarms, monitoring and care communication systems for senior citizens; and two other software companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: The vice president of Russian oil giant Lukoil, Fedun started out as a professional military man. Born in Kiev, Ukraine, he graduated from the Rostov Higher Command School and served as an officer in the nuclear missile forces. With the fall of communism Fedun adroitly transformed himself, learning the workings of financial markets, starting a financial consultancy that helped Vagit Alekperov set up Lukoil. Since then Fedun has coordinated Lukoil’s privatization (in which managers like himself got big stakes) and its operations on Western capital markets. Now owns big stakes in Lukoil, closely affiliated investment bank Nikoil, various newspaper and TV assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother William runs family’s Hong Kong-based import-export firm Li & Fung for clients like Disney, Coca-Cola and Kohl’s. MIT, Harvard-educated Victor joined company 1973, chairman since 1989. Also chairman of Prumerica Financial Asia; active in Hong Kong public life as head of airport authority.

name: Billionaires
bio: While brother and fellow billionaire Victor is chairman, William is managing director of Li  & Fung, the global outsourcing company that supplies clothes and fashion accessories to retailers like American Eagle Outfitters and Abercrombie & Fitch. It has suppliers throughout Asia and can quickly shift orders from one country to another, depending on political and economic winds.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of five surviving grandchildren of famed publisher William Randolph Hearst. William’s father, George, was a prospector, land baron and U.S. senator who “won” failing broadsheet San Francisco Examiner as payment for gambling debt in 1880. Only child, William (d. 1951) assumed control in 1887, built nation’s largest newspaper chain via sensational “yellow” journalism. Today Hearst Corp. owns magazines (Cosmopolitan, Esquire, Good Housekeeping), newspapers (Houston Chronicle, San Francisco Chronicle), broadcasting (Hearst-Argyle) and cable (stakes in ESPN, A&E and Lifetime). Partner in Silicon Valley venture capital outfit Kleiner, Perkins.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father built one of nation's first radio stations 1923; added TV. Stanley took charge 1981, pushed into satellite delivery. Hubbard Broadcasting now 13 TV stations, radio, big stake in USSB. Also satellite news-gathering service Conus Communications.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Self-made billionaire Saleh Kamel seems to have lost his golden touch of late: Though his Dallah Albaraka conglomerate--built through lucrative contracting deals with the Saudi Arabian government--seems healthy, other business ventures, into Islamic banking and media, have faltered. Kamel has reportedly lost more than $1 billion building a media empire that spans the Middle East.

Built his empire on the strength of contracting deals with the Saudi government. Expanded into banking and real estate before venturing into media, his true passion. Founded MBC (Middle East Broadcasting Center) and ART (Arab Radio & Television), the latter a chronic moneyloser and cash drain. Owns a majority of Dallah Albaraka, a conglomerate that runs vast Islamic banking operations, as well as real estate, construction and manufacturing interests. The ailing Islamic banking business is undergoing a massive overhaul. Like many wealthy Saudis, Kamel confronts allegations that some of his business interests may have been exploited by terrorist elements. Kamel denies any wrongdoing. 

From 2004 bio:
Saleh Kamel
Self-made billionaire built up his Dallah Albaraka conglomerate, an empire of finance and leasing companies and Islamic banks, though the latter have reportedely faltered in recent years. Also entered the television space: reportedly spent over $1 billion building a media empire that spans the Middle East. Word is that many of these media ventures have yet to turn a profit.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Gary Burrell (see) controls global positioning systems manufacturer Garmin. Met while working as engineers at AlliedSignal; struck out on own in 1989. First customers: U.S. Army during first Gulf war. Now manufactures devices for aerospace and marine industries, as well as for individuals.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner George Roberts (see), back in the limelight after sale of Primedia&#39s New York agazine to Bruce Wasserstein for $55 million in December. First cousins and famed “barbarians at the gate,” Kravis and Roberts partnered with Bear Stearns mentor Jerome Kohlberg (see) to form leveraged-buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts. Bought underperforming companies using junk bonds, reworked balance sheets, sold for profit. Best known for $25 billion RJR Nabisco buyout 1989. Kohlberg exited in 1987; remaining duo favors buy-and-hold strategy over bold, highly leveraged bets.

name: Billionaires
bio: The laptop tycoon is back on the Billionaires list after a one-year absence. Quanta Computer's stock price rose nearly 50% in the past twelve months while revenues soared 65%. Still, profit margins have sunk recently, prompting Lam to diversify into servers and flat-screen TVs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest son of J.W. Marriott Sr. (d. 1985), who started root beer stand in 1927. Opened first Marriott hotel in 1957. With older brother J. Willard Jr. (see) split empire in 1993. Richard chairman of Host Marriott. J.W. Jr. chairs management arm of Marriott International.

name: Billionaires
bio: Has owned and operated candy purveyor Haribo for 58 years. (Riegel is only slightly younger than Haribo’s best known product, Gummi Bears.) While brother Paul oversees production and technical issues at the privately held concern, which last year posted an estimated $1.75 billion in sales, Hans is the brain trust behind new products. Among his confections: over 200 brands, including Vademecum sugar-free gum, Haribo Gummi Bears and Maoam fruit chewies.  The former men’s badminton champion says he consults children’s television and comic books for inspiration.

name: Billionaires
bio: Roberts, with partner Henry Kravis (see), back in the limelight after Primedia&#39s sale of New York magazine to Bruce Wasserstein for $55 million in December. First cousins and famed “barbarians at the gate” joined with fellow Bear Stearns mentor Jerome Kohlberg (see) to form leveraged-buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts. Bought underperforming companies using junk bonds, reworked balance sheets, sold for profit. Best known for $25 billion RJR Nabisco buyout 1989. Kohlberg exited in 1987; duo favors buy-and-hold strategy over bold, highly leveraged bets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman emeritus of Peter Kiewit Sons’, construction outfit where he became president in 1979. Steered company into high-speed fiber-optic networks, public/private toll roads, geothermal power plant, MFS Communications.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former top salesman for Oracle left 1990 after chief Larry Ellison (see) ditched plans to bring Siebel’s sales automation software to market. Founded Siebel Systems 1993; IPO 1996. Struggled through tech downturn, but regained footing in the rebound: Spent $70 million in November (2003) to buy UpShot Corp. to run sales management software for client companies over the internet.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime Palo Alto residential real estate broker now one of Silicon Valley’s largest commercial landlords. Weak tech market shifting focus back to apartments: plans to raze three commercial buildings in San Jose to build residential apartments. Son, John Michael, active in business.

name: Billionaires
bio: The chief executive of $590 million (sales) Meriton Apartments joins the billionaires list for the first time, riding Sydney’s residential property boom and the strength of the Aussie dollar. His simple four-decade formula? Invest in low-cost, second-rate neighborhoods; offer low-cost, second-rate housing. Born in China to Russian parents who fled the country during the Bolshevik Revolution, learned about real estate development as a child visiting his father, a builder, at work sites in Tientsin, China. Immigrated to Australia at age 14. Triguboff may face lean years ahead with concerns that the market is already saturated with Meriton-like housing. He’s not worried, telling the Aussie business press, “The aim in life is not to die rich. It is to spend as much money as you can afford.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Like his old friend Lukoil Vice President Leonid Fedun, Tsvetkov started out in the military. He finished the Air Force Academy, served with Soviet forces in Afghanistan and reached the rank of lieutenant colonel. When the Soviet Union collapsed, Tsvetkov resigned his commission, started a new career as an investor. In 1993, together with the top managers of Lukoil, Tsvetkov established investment company Nikoil, whose first task was to make sure that Lukoil managers would be the big winners in their company’s 1994 privatization. Today Tsvetkov has a big stake in Lukoil; his investment bank, Nikoil, is acquiring retail bank UralSib to become one of Russia’s largest private financial institutions.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former partner in Endemol, the Dutch TV production outfit credited with pioneering the reality show format with hits like Fear Factor and Big Brother. Earned billionaire status after the sale of Endemol to Spanish telecom giant Telefónica in 2000 for $5.3 billion. Today van den Ende chairs Stage Holding, a $760 million (sales) musical theater company—and Endemol spinoff—behind such Broadway megahits as Mamma Mia and 42nd Street. No doubt van den Ende is brushing up on his Spanish. Stage Holding has partnered with CIE, a Mexican live entertainment company, to produce musicals in Spain.

name: Billionaires
bio: Princeton grad and Harvard M.B.A. did upper-management legwork at Procter & Gamble, Keds and Hasbro before signing on as chief executive of online auction site Ebay in 1998. Strong survivor of Internet shakeout thanks to explosive growth in trading community. “Meg” spends time offline fly-fishing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Canada, got into real estate after degrees from Wharton, Harvard Law. Started Boston Properties 1970: built warehouse, office space in Boston, Washington, D.C. Second career as publisher: owns U.S. News & World Report, New York’s Daily News; sold Fast Company magazine for $365 million near tech market peak.

name: Billionaires
bio: Visionary who turned a small Marseilles catering outfit into Sodexho Alliance, one of the world’s largest catering companies, serving up tasties to an astonishingly diverse list of institutions from Morehouse College to the Swedish army. Earnings fell last year with the falling euro and the torpid worldwide economic climate, but investors are cautiously optimistic that the recovery will boost profits. Son François-Xavier, 38, took over the company&#39s struggling British operations in January, prompting speculation that the heir is apparent.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Bernard Marcus, founded hardware juggernaut Home Depot in 1978 after getting axed from now-defunct Handy Dan chain. Took public three years later. Today Home Depot has 1,600 stores, $58 billion in sales. Partners are now retired. Blank focusing on another kind of fan: owner of pro football’s Atlanta Falcons added 21,000 season-ticket holders in 2002, sold out every home game.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of the Evergreen Group, a large transportation group based in Taiwan with large shipping and aviation interests. Group’s history dates back to 1968 when it operated small ships to transport cargo. Today it has a fleet of 100 container vessels and ranks as one of the world’s largest shipping companies. In 1989 Chang stated to expand into aviation services.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of five surviving grandchildren of famed publisher William Randolph Hearst. William’s father, George, was a prospector, land baron and U.S. senator who “won” failing broadsheet San Francisco Examiner as payment for gambling debt in 1880. Only child, William (d. 1951) assumed control in 1887, built nation’s largest newspaper chain via sensational “yellow” journalism. Today Hearst Corp. owns magazines (Cosmopolitan, Esquire, Good Housekeeping), newspapers (Houston Chronicle, San Francisco Chronicle), broadcasting (Hearst-Argyle) and cable (stakes in ESPN, A&E and Lifetime).

name: Billionaires
bio: Back on the list this year, thanks to a strong euro and improved third-quarter results. Son of a carpenter, owns 53.1% of $7.9 billion (sales) conglomerate Sonae GSPS, Portugal’s leading retailer, best known for its Modelo Continente superstores and supermarkets. Other interests include real estate, communications, shopping centers, a daily newspaper, a radio station and a manufacturer of wood panels.

name: Billionaires
bio: Erstwhile owner of pro football’s San Francisco 49ers has finally severed ties with the team after settling long-running dispute with sister, Denise, over family assets. All the richer with $70 million payout, large stake in Simon Property. Father, Edward Sr., started real estate, racetrack empire in 1944 with a strip mall in Youngstown, Ohio.

name: Billionaires
bio: Largest private forestland holder in North America (1.5 million acres) making peace with conservation crowd by selling thousands of acres in Sierra Nevada to preservationists. “Red” learned the timber business from father, who started out with makeshift sawmills in family’s backyard. Took Sierra Pacific Industries public 1969; bought it back five years later.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built family’s scrap metal business into a cascade of assets in media, utilities and oil. Investments include a shared 25% stake in German media behemoth Bertelsmann. Known as a workaholic who claims he’ll never retire, Baron Frere is a connoisseur of fine wine and co-owner, with French billionaire Bernard Arnault, of the Château Cheval Blanc vineyard.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stock of his Benesse Corp., best-known for its satellite cram school, is up 66% in the past 12 months. In a management shakeup last year, Fukutake, who had been president since 1986, brought in an outsider to help run the company. He remains chief executive and chairman. Its core education courses, which it’s been teaching since 1969, continue to shrink due to changes in Japaense educational system and fewer school-age kids.  So the company is diversifying into new areas like day-care and nursing care at nursing homes or in-home.  Also has partnership with U.S. toy company LeapFrog  to develop Japanese versions of its hugely popular educational toys.

name: Billionaires
bio: Political science major married Linda Marie Pace, daughter of Pace salsa founder David Pace. Started on Pace production line cutting up vegetables, found niche in sales department. Became president 1977. With wife, bought company from other family members. When wife sued for divorce in 1991, bought her half for $95 million. Sold the whole enchilada four years later to Campbell Soup for $1.1 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: The boss of Daily Mail and General Trust proved detractors wrong —he may be young, but he’s more than capable of steering a media empire through these troubled times. DMGT reported a slight 2% increase in pretax profits last year and is predicting a return to higher growth in the coming year. In a year when most newspapers saw circulation rolls decline, the Daily Mail added subscribers. Jonathan Harmsworth, also known as Viscount Rothermere, has made no indication he’ll tinker with DMGT’s controversial share structure, which gives his family control of the voting rights despite a minority stake in equity.

William’s father, George, was a prospector, land baron and U.S. senator who “won” failing broadsheet San Francisco Examiner as payment for gambling debt in 1880. Only child, William (d. 1951) assumed control in 1887, built nation’s largest newspaper chain via sensational “yellow” journalism. name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of coffee magnate Max Herz who watched her five children battle over management of their father’s legacy, Tchibo Holding, a large German retail group. Said to have played peacemaker in the recent accords—Günter and Daniela sold their stake to their three brothers for an estimated $5 billion. Like son Joachim, she retains a 15% stake in Tchibo Holding.

name: Billionaires
bio: Air Force veteran converted single gas station into oil business replete with stations, convenience stores and refineries. Began investing proceeds in Utah, Idaho, Wyoming real estate. Bona fide ski bum. His Sun Valley Ranch resort is home to Herb Allen’s (see) annual media mogul conference. Also owns Utah’s Snowbasin ski resort and 377-room Grand America Hotel, venues for the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started in D.A.’s office, formed own firm 1955. Took up personal injury cases, struck gold with Texaco-Pennzoil case 1987: received estimated $345 million in fees. Now defending one of Enron’s law firms, Vinson & Elkins.

name: Billionaires
bio: USC dropout got start making motorcycle grips in 1975; later goggles, sunglasses. Shrewd marketer built brand recognition by enticing high-profile athletes to sport his trendy Oakley shades for free. Diversified into shoes, watches, apparel. Self-proclaimed “mad scientist” obsessed with innovation: owns more than 600 patents. Recently designed assault boot and eyewear for U.S. Elite Special Forces.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eldest son of J.W. Marriott Sr. (d. 1985), who started root beer stand in 1927. Opened first Marriott hotel in 1957. With younger brother Richard (see) split empire in 1993. Richard chairman of Host Marriott. J.W. Jr. chairs management arm of Marriott International.

name: Billionaires
bio: The frothy stock market tripled the value of his shares in French telecom Alcatel, which in 1999 bought his Newbridge Networks for $7 billion. His two latest ventures,  Ottawa-based Mitel and March Networks, develop Internet telephony and video applications. Not surprisingly, they’re deep in the red, though Matthews has hopes for an IPO. Wales-born Matthews owns lavish golf resort Celtic Manor there. With 400 rooms and three courses, it’s slated to host the famed Ryder Cup in 2010. Back in Ottawa, his new upscale Brookstreet Hotel boasts 276 rooms—and even serves as a ready-made testing ground for his companies’ telecom products.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold grocery distribution business to tennis partner Sam Walton for cash and Wal-Mart stock in 1990. Now owns pro baseball’s Houston Astros. Moved team into new stadium 2000, renamed Minute Maid Park (formerly Enron Field); favorable lease lets team keep most of the revenue. Chairman of Baylor University’s board of regents.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brother of Dirk and Robert Ziff (see both). Father, William Ziff Jr., built Ziff-Davis publishing empire (PC magazine, Car & Driver, Boating), sold for $1.4 billion in 1994, retired to Florida. Siblings reinvest proceeds via Ziff Brothers Investments: hedge funds, corporate debt, equities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brother of Dirk and Daniel Ziff (see both). Father, William Ziff Jr., built Ziff-Davis publishing empire (PC magazine, Car & Driver, Boating), sold for $1.4 billion in 1994, retired to Florida. Siblings reinvest proceeds via Ziff Brothers Investments: hedge funds, corporate debt, equities.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner, Richard Peery, Arrillaga is one of Silicon Valley’s biggest commercial landlords. Still feeling their tenants’ pain: vacancies at their estimated 12 million square feet topping 20% in 2003. Partners built their fortunes on farmland they bought in the 1960s. Shun debt and the media. Arrillaga is a big donor to alma mater Stanford University. Peery’s son Jason joined company in 1998.

name: Billionaires
bio: Market upturn easing stress on Bass family fortune after liquidity crunch, bad tech bets forced Sid to sell large chunk of Disney stake to meet margin call. Father, Perry, built on oil fortune inherited from uncle Sid Richardson (d. 1951). Handed business to son Sid in 1968, prompting younger son, Robert, to break out on his own. Investments include Hawthorne Financial, Iomega, oil and gas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wife’s complaints about balancing her checkbook prompted former P&G product manager to develop personal-finance software. Founded Intuit with programmer Tom Proulx. Shipped first copy of Quicken in 1984; soon introduced QuickBooks for small businesses and TurboTax tax preparation software. Today Intuit has over 20 million users, giving Cook plenty of money to fund M.B.A. program at University of Wisconsin’s business school.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heady days for the Chicago-born stock promoter. Made his fortune when his Diamond Fields Resources uncovered one of the world’s biggest nickel deposits while searching for diamonds in Voisey’s Bay, Newfoundland. It was sold in 1996 for $3.1 billion. Now he’s touting a copper and gold deposit discovered in Mongolia by his Nasdaq-listed Ivanhoe Mines. Can lightening strike twice for a guy nicknamed “Toxic Bob” by his critics? After increasing his stake, Ivanhoe’s value soared when the deposit was estimated to bear some $40 billion worth of metal. Ivanhoe’s stock is up about 200% in the last year. A second venture, Ivanhoe Energy, prospecting for gas in California and China.

name: Billionaires
bio: The billionaire jack-of-all-trades. While most of his wealth is tied up in the CFS Gandel Retail Trust, a $2 billion (market capitalization) real estate investment trust, Gandel also owns or shares ownership in two Australian shopping centers and five retirement villages. It all started when he inherited a woman’s clothing retailer from his parents, Polish immigrants who arrived in Melbourne just before World War II. Sold it in 1985 to his brother-in-law. Proceeds helped him develop Aussie’s Priceline, a discount retailer of women’s cosmetics and beauty products. He and his wife collect Japanese art.

name: Billionaires
bio: High school dropout sought better TV reception by building his own $1,500 antenna tower; later built, bought cable franchises. Sold Cablevision Industries to Time Warner in 1996 for $2.8 billion. Still owns large Time Warner stake, but fares better with private investment boutique Granite Associates.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shopping-mall magnate saw big rise in the value of his Super Bowl champs, Tampa Bay Buccaneers; budding sports tycoon flirted with buying Los Angeles Dodgers from Rupert Murdoch, but failed to reach a deal. Also holds interest in English soccer club Manchester United. Family's Zapata Corp. owns stake in fish-oil business; recently spent $30 million for stake in Safety Components International, maker of airbag fabric for automobiles.

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened first store 1972 in Oklahoma City to sell handmade wooden picture frames. Today Hobby Lobby: 309 craft stores in 27 states. Estimated sales: $1.1 billion. Low-tech retailer shuns bar codes, big wholesale suppliers; prefers buying directly from factories in Asia. Devout Christian bought Mel Tillis theater in Branson, Mo., donated it to local church group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Husband John Murdoch Harbert III (d. 1995) turned $6,000 in craps winnings into construction colossus: airports, pipelines, power plants. Son Raymond manages the money; Marguerite hunts game on Georgia plantation.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Montreal
78. Divorced, remarried, 4 children
Berlin-born Jarislowsky moved to the U.S. in 1941. M.B.A. from Harvard in 1949, then moved to Canada. Started Montreal-based money manager Jarislowsky, Fraser in 1955. Today the firm manages $32 billion for pension funds and high-net-worth individuals. The longtime shareholder advocate cofounded Canadian Coalition for Good Governance two years ago and recently publicly chastised embattled newspaper baron—and onetime pal—Conrad Black. He’s also a separatist, with a twist: believes Montreal should split from both Canada and Quebec and become city-state, à la Hong Kong. Eclectic art collector: jade, Canadian paintings, Chinese furniture, Eskimo artifacts. Owns private island off coast of British Columbia.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners Jay Baker and John Herma took over Kohl’s department store chain in 1986 management buyout. Expanded 40-store family outfit started in 1962; now a 494-branch empire in 34 states.

name: Billionaires
bio: Accordion-playing fire-breather turned circus icon, Laliberte founded Cirque du Soleil in 1984 with a gang of street performing friends. Initially funded by the Canadian government, the Montreal-based circus, which has no animals, no speaking and no star performers, became a for-profit group in 1985. Laliberte eventually bought out his majority partner in 2000. Hit the jackpot in 1991 when Steve Wynn brought Cirque to Las Vegas. Today the $500 million (2003 revenues) group has three permanent shows in Sin City (Mystere, O, Zumanity), with a fourth on its way. Produces a total of nine shows. Other revenues derived from CD, DVD sales and television licenses. Known for lavish parties, Laliberte, who dreams of one day traveling into space, owns 95% of the company. Cirque donates 1% of sales to charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lemann can thank investment banking and investing for the bulk of his fortune, but it wasn’t always all work and no play for this wiry Brazilian. Soon after graduating from Harvard in 1961, Lemann joined the European tennis circuit for 18 months. He won the Swiss nationals and even played in Wimbledon. Back in Brazil he founded investment bank Garantia in 1971, which he eventually sold to CS First Boston for a reported $675 million in 1998. The biggest piece of his wealth is now his 8% stake in AmBev—the world’s fifth-largest brewer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Younger son of the venerated Li Ka-shing. Borrowed $250 million from his father and launched StarTV in 1991; later sold the satellite TV operation to Rupert Murdoch for $950 million. Used proceeds to start Pacific Century Group, with interests in real estate, financial services and technology. In 2000 his publicly traded PCCW Ltd acquired Cable & Wireless HKT, the largest provider of fixed-line telecommunication in Hong Kong for $28 billion. To pay for the acquisition, drew down $12 billion in loans.  Today debt is $3.9 billion. Recently stepped down as PCCW chief executive but remains chairman. Li is a licensed jet plane pilot and avid scuba diver.

name: Billionaires
bio: Surviving son of Bob Magness, who founded cable television giant TCI. Inherited fortune after drawn-out court fight with stepmother. Prefers to keep a low profile but lately popping up in Denver society after 2002 marriage to Celestial Seasonings tea heiress and So Low contemporary sportswear entrepreneur Sarah Siegel.

name: Billionaires
bio: “Red” dropped out of law school to peddle cars. Owned first dealership at 25. Made real fortune with Clear Channel Communications, radio outfit started in 1972 with Lowry Mays (see). With daughter Marsha, focuses on pro football franchise Minnesota Vikings.

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of a respected Soviet physicist, Melnichenko excelled in his studies and entered the prestigious Mathematics & Physics Institute of Moscow State University. In 1991 communism fell and Melnichenko dropped out. Together with some schoolmates he started a tourism business, sold computers, established a chain of currency exchange booths; in 1993 founded MDM Bank, which handled the accounts of oil tycoon Roman Abramovich and other businessmen favored by the Kremlin. In 2000, after an attempt to sign up the Ministry of Atomic Energy as a client failed, Melnichenko teamed up with metals trader Sergei Popov and began accumulating an industrial empire that now includes chemicals, coal mines, steel mills and a 10% stake in Russia’s electric monopoly.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Tel Aviv-born movie mogul responsible for megahits like Pretty Woman and L.A. Confidential founded New Regency Productions in 1991. His own background is the stuff of movies. A former biochemistry student and soccer player, he successfully transformed his family’s fledgling fertilizer company into a multimillion-dollar chemicals business. Parlayed that into a role as an arms dealer for Israel, which he coyly discussed in a 60 Minutes interview in 2000. (Milchan denies he was an arms dealer, but admits to acting as an intermediary between the country and defense contractors like Raytheon.) In the Eighties began bankrolling films for directors Sergio Leone and Martin Scorsese. Counts among his friends Israeli government officials (Shimon Peres), business moguls (Rupert Murdoch) and Hollywood icons (Robert De Niro). Famous for his love of all things Israeli—he underwrites the Israeli Network, which transmits over cable and satellite in the U.S. and Canada.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner John Arrillaga, Peery is one of Silicon Valley’s biggest commercial landlords. Still feeling their tenants’ pain: vacancies at their estimated 12 million square feet topping 20% in 2003. Partners built their fortunes on farmland they bought in the 1960s. Shun debt and the media. Arrillaga is a big donor to alma mater Stanford University. Peery’s son Jason joined company in 1998.

name: Billionaires
bio: Great-grandchild of Richard Beatty Mellon, founder of T. Mellon & Sons, predecessor of today’s Mellon Bank. Richard controls Tribune-Review as well as a number of radio stations in western Pennsylvania. As chairman of Sarah Scaife Foundation, supports conservative groups like the Heritage Foundation, the Social Philosophy and Policy Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers Dieter and Stefan von Holtzbrinck, owns a third of German publishing house, Verlagsgruppe Holtzbrinck, top publisher of books, newspapers and magazines. She herself heads the S. Fischer Verlag unit, a publishing company founded in 1886.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bartender’s son grew up in Illinois housing project. Peddled life insurance in college, then took jobs in construction, oil. In 1988 started Excel Communications, multilevel-marketer of long-distance service. Took public eight years later. Sold to Teleglobe in 1998 for $3.5 billion. Sights now set on horses: Last year’s Kentucky Derby and Preakness winner, Funny Cide, was conceived on his WinStar Farm in Kentucky.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited 33% of Holtzbrinck Verlag, one of Germany’s largest publishing houses. Took over management when his half-brother Dieter retired in May 2001. Holtzbrinck, with its focus on business titles like Handelsblatt and Wirtschaftswoche, has been feeling the slump in the German media sector, the most severe since WW II. Group turnover dropped slightly in 2002 to $2.78 billion and is expected to drop again in 2003. Nevertheless, Stefan is optimistic. “The group will end the year [2003] very well,” he is quoted as saying. Growth will likely come from abroad, specifically from the book publishing segment and Die Zeit, the now-profitable weekend magazine.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of John T. Dorrance, founder of Campbell Soup, inventor of condensed-soup process. Thoroughbred breeder, owner of Live Oak Stud farm in Ocala, Fla.

name: Billionaires
bio: Martha may be foundering, but Oprah still flying high on television (The Oprah Winfrey Show, The Dr. Phil Show), in print (O! The Oprah Magazine remains a big seller at the newsstand) and online (Oprah.com visited by 2 million fans a month).

name: Billionaires
bio: Casino visionary is back in the mix, three years after selling his Mirage Resorts to Kirk Kerkorian’s (see) MGM Grand. Raised $450 million in October 2002 with public offering of Wynn Resorts; stock up 140% since. Using proceeds to finance Wynn Las Vegas: $2.4 billion resort with 2,700 rooms, Ferrari and Maserati dealerships, permanent space for Wynn’s vaunted art collection. Megaresort scheduled to open April 2005. Along with Sheldon Adelson (see), snagged one of three coveted Macau gaming licenses.

name: Billionaires
bio: The lone billionaire from mainland China. His father Rong Yiren was tapped by Deng Xiaoping in the late 1970s to help relaunch China's economy; he himself made a fortune in everything from infrastructure to property. Yung (Rong Zhijian) took over as chairman in 1990 and now controls an 18% stake in Hong-Kong listed CITIC Pacific. One new area of investment for the conglomerate last year was the steel industry.  Citic's stock is up almost 50% in the past twelve months, thanks largely to investor excitement about opportunities in China.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of Russia’s wealthiest industrialists was largely unknown until five years ago. Abramov finished the Moscow Institute of Physics & Technology in 1982, studied for a doctorate, headed up the commercial department of a prestigious physics laboratory. After the fall of communism, went into business for himself. Established  a precursor to EvrazHolding in 1992; made a fortune exporting metals and coal from the Ural mountains and Siberia. After Russia’s financial collapse in 1998, bought up steel companies and coal mines on the cheap, also a big stake in Russia’s electric monopoly. His purchase of the big port of Nakhodka, in the Far East, said to have been spurred by his love of fishing in the area.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned small scrap metal business into metals and mining company with copper, zinc and aluminum assets. In 2001 snagged India’s first large-scale privatization, Bharat Aluminum Company, followed by purchase of state-owned zinc company. His biggest move: a December 2003 listing of his company, $1 billion (sales) Vedanta, on the London Stock Exchange. His stake was worth more than $900 million at press time.

name: Billionaires
bio: Investor finding new passion for real estate: purchased 1 million square feet of L.A.-area commercial space in the past year. Also owns luxury car dealerships, beer distributor Ace Beverage.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of Greek immigrants was born in Detroit, raised in Pasadena. Started off running Palm Springs grocery, graduated to buying and selling corner lots at busy intersections for gas stations. Turned to apartments 1968. Today Arnel & Affiliates: real estate outfit manages apartments, owns commercial property in southern California. Active Republican helped open first permanent U.S. trade office in Madrid in January; now the U.S. ambassador to Spain.

name: Billionaires
bio: President of Chicago developer JMB Realty was nearly knocked out in 1990s real estate collapse. Stuck with it, now enjoying rising values. L.A. skyscraper new home for MGM. With Pritzker family (see), developing Niagara Falls casino.

name: Billionaires
bio: With Stanford grad pal Larry Page (see), created Internet search engine Google in late 1990s. Name popularly used as verb, scours content from more than 3 billion Web sites. Long-term goal: index all the world’s public information. Duo raised $25 million from venture capital firms 1999. Today each partners’ stake worth more than $1 billion, perhaps far greater if long-expected IPO lives up to the hype.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Min Kao (see) controls global positioning systems manufacturer Garmin. Met while working as engineers at AlliedSignal; struck out on own in 1989. First customers: U.S. Army during first Gulf war. Stock up 100% since 2000 IPO.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turkey’s youngest self-made billionaire. Transformed a small auto-parts business into Park Group, a $1.4 billion (sales) conglomerate with interests in textiles, energy and mining. Owns enormous soda ash reserve, used for making glass. As the owner of Turkey’s third-largest media group, Ciner, along with other Turkish media magnates, is a target of the Turkish parliament, which is considering new legislation to rein in these large owners. Curries favor with the locals by building schools in Turkey and donating them to the government. Syrian ties: a bus factory and an olive oil processing plant under development.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wharton grad got start trading options at Gruntal & Co. 1978; made $8,000 profit on first day. Founded hedge fund SAC Capital with $20 million 1992; now manages $4 billion in assets. Known for moving markets: firm reportedly trades 20 million shares a day, accounting for as much as 3% of the NYSE’s daily volume. Secretive investor thought to command highest performance fee in the business: keeps 50% of the profits once certain benchmarks are met.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kingpin of Turkey’s medical and pharmaceutical sector draws his family name from the Turkish honorary title of head pharmacist bestowed on his grandfather 95 years ago. Father Nejat started making drugs in 1952, passed away 41 years later. Bulent recently named one of Europe’s top 45 industrialists. Locked in a battle with his biggest customer, the Turkish government, on changing competitive rules in generic drugs market. Also angling for a slice of Iraq’s $2 billion drug market. His Eczacibasi Holdings has a contract manufacturing agreement with Roche Group to make pills. He and his wife scouting Istanbul homes—inculding a former U.S. consulate—to serve as a museum for his extensive collection of Turkish contemporary painters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ford patriarch presides over century-old automaker founded by grandfather Henry. Son William Jr. serves as CEO. Owner of pro football's Detroit Lions.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bought pro football’s Dallas Cowboys and stadium 14 years ago with $140 million in oil money. Good investment: “America’s team” now worth $851 million. Also has holdings in gas, oil, real estate, which he claims Forbes perennially underestimates: “In my mind, those assets are as valuable as the team.” Won battle with NFL brass last year to manufacture and sell Cowboys merchandise. Says it was profitable after just 1 year. Hired headstrong coach Bill Parcells this year, but plays down any chance of clashing egos. “Bill is a very positive asset.”

name: Billionaires
bio: An original investor in $1.6 billion (sales) Amdocs, a customer relationship management and billing software firm for large telecom outfits. (One out of every two phone calls made in North America relies on Amdocs software.) Has cashed out an estimated $900 million worth of shares since Amdocs went public in 1998. He’s also a part-owner of Aurec Group, an Israeli-based private equity firm with cable and telecom investments. The press-shy former diver founded Coral World International, a string of aquariums in Eilat, Israel; Maui; and Australia.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Son of English father, Polish mother, raised in Portland, Ore. Sold magazines, lemonade during the Depression before getting physics master’s from UCLA. Founded and sold aerospace companies Spectrolab and Heliotek, 1960s. Funded Pacesetter Systems (rechargeable pacemakers), MiniMed (insulin pumps), Advanced Bionics (neural stimulation); sold parts to Medtronic for $4.2 billion in 2001. Now 
focusing on biomed firm Mannkind Corp. Philanthropic, especially medical research.

name: Billionaires
bio: With Stanford grad pal Sergey Brin (see), created Internet search engine Google in late 1990s. Name popularly used as verb, scours content from more than 3 billion Web sites. Long-term goal: index all the world’s public information. Duo raised $25 million from venture capital firms 1999. Today each partners’ stake worth more than $1 billion, perhaps far greater if expected IPO lives up to the hype.

name: Billionaires
bio: Second largest shareholder in Hennes & Mauritz, the successful Swedish ready-to-wear chain founded in 1947 by her late father Erling Persson. Lottie, as she likes to be called, leaves the management of the $7.7 billion concern in the capable hands of brother Stefan.

name: Billionaires
bio: A trained nuclear engineer, graduated from University of Milan. He taught at the University of Milan, then became an AC Nielsen researcher before joining the family firm in 1976. He turned the family's little, ailing Naples-based drug wholesaler into the second largest drug wholesaler in Europe. Hobby: yachts. Lives in tax-haven Monaco but can be found at the Ritz when in London.

name: Billionaires
bio: Largely unknown until a few years ago, Popov is co-owner of the MDM Group.  Studied to be an ordinary electrical engineer, but the fall of communism in 1991 gave him his chance to make a fortune. Throughout the 1990s he made his way through the murky world of metals and oil trading in the Urals and Siberia. As a client of MDM Bank, he got to know the bank’s owner, Andrei Melnichenko. After the collapse of the ruble in 1998 he convinced Melnichenko to buy up Russian steel mills, chemicals companies and coal mines on the cheap. Good move: Those assets, co-owned by the two partners, are up sharply in value.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Not even Joanne Kathleen Rowling could have imagined the power her pubescent wizard possessed. The former welfare mother’s five Harry Potter books have sold 250 million copies. Potter movies have grossed $2 billion. But the Potter craze may have peaked. Mattel reports 
that sales of its Potter toys are softening.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Brazilian widow of billionaire banker Edmond Safra continues to make the social and philanthropic pages on both sides of the Atlantic. Last November she opened the Edmond J. Safra Hall at the Museum of Jewish Heritage in lower Manhattan with a gala affair that attracted the city’s social elite. In London she reportedly sold one grand home and bought another.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shopping mall mogul, former chairman of Sotheby’s released from federal prison in May after serving 10-month sentence for fixing prices with rival auction house. Things no easier on the outside: his mall chain facing takeover bid led by rival Simon Property. Resigned from executive posts at both Sotheby’s and Taubman Centers; remains largest shareholder in both, but looking to dump Sotheby’s stake. Sons now run day-to-day business; Al remains active in Detroit arts scene.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bought his first building in 1951; opened his first restaurant in 1966. Over the years has amassed a real estate fortune. His $607 million (sales) Olav Thon Gruppen owns 320 properties in Norway and 18 abroad, including 41 hotels, restaurants and pubs in Oslo, shopping centers, retail shops, a tobacco importer and even a manufacturer of raw ingredients for the soap and cosmetics industry

name: Billionaires
bio: Controls the Rimbunan Hijau group, a timber giant with concessions in Papua New Guinea, central Africa, Brazil, New Zealand and Malaysia. In the past decade he’s also become a media mogul whose properties include Chinese language newspapers in Malaysia and Hong Kong. Now looking to boost circulation of its newspaper Ming Pao in the U.S., particularly in San Francisco.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of John T. Dorrance, founder of Campbell Soup, inventor of condensed-soup process. Left half his fortune to son, John Jr. (d. 1989), the rest to his 3 daughters. Hope: an active donor and supporter of the St. Michael’s Country Day School in Rhode Island.
